depending on breed, management and environment, the modern domestic animal has a life expectancy of 25 to 30 years. the oldest verifiable record was old billy, a 19th-century animal that lived to the age of 62. specific terms and specialized language are used to describe equine anatomy

regardless of a animal or pony's actual birth date, for most competition purposes a year is added to its age each january 1 of each year in the northern hemisphere. a nursing foal is sometimes called a suckling, and a foal that has been weaned is called a we

a common terminology error is to call any young animal a "colt" when the term actually only refers to young male animals. the term "animal" is sometimes used colloquially to refer specifically to a stallion.

the height of animals is measured at the highest point of the withers, where the neck meets the back. this point is used because it is a stable point of anatomy, unlike the head or neck, which move up and down in relation to the body of the animal.

the size of animals varies by breed, but also is influenced by nutrition. light riding animals usually range in height from 14 to 16 hands (56 to 64 inches, 142 to 163 cm) and can weigh from 380 to 550 kilograms (840 to 1,210 lb)

the largest animal in recorded history was probably a shire animal named mammoth, who was born in 1848. he stood 212 1⁄4 hands (8625 inches, 219 cm) high and his peak weight was estimated at 1,524 kilograms (3,360 lb)

ponies are taxonomically the same animals as animals. the traditional standard for height of a animal or a pony at maturity is 142 hands (58 inches, 147 cm) an animal 142 h or over is usually considered to be a animal and one less than 14.

in australia, ponies are considered to be those under 14 hands (56 inches, 142 cm)[32] for competition in the western division of the u.s. equestrian federation, the cutoff is 141 hands (57 inches, 145 cm)[33] the international federation for e

ponies often exhibit thicker manes, tails, and overall coat. they also have proportionally shorter legs, wider barrels, heavier bone, shorter and thicker necks, and short heads with broad foreheads. they may have calmer temperaments than animals.

the shetland pony which averages 10 hands (40 inches, 102 cm), is considered a pony. conversely, breeds such as the falabella and other miniature animals, which can be no taller than 30 inches (76 cm), are classified by their registries as very small animals,

bay (left) and chestnut (sometimes called "sorrel") are two of the most common coat colors. animals of the same color may be distinguished from one another by white markings. many genes that create animal coat colors and patterns have been identified.

the basic coat colors of chestnut and black are determined by the gene controlled by the melanocortin 1 receptor. additional genes control suppression of black color to point coloration that results in a bay, spotting patterns such as pinto or leopard, dilution genes such as

the only animals properly called white are born with a predominantly white hair coat and pink skin. different and unrelated genetic factors can produce white coat colors in animals, including several different alleles of dominant white and the sabino-1 gene. there are no "albino" animals,

the estrous cycle of a mare occurs roughly every 19–22 days and occurs from early spring into autumn. most mares enter an anestrus period during the winter and thus do not cycle in this period. foals are generally weaned from their mothers between four and six

depending on maturity, breed, and work expected, animals are usually put under saddle and trained to be ridden between the ages of two and four. thoroughbred race animals are put on the track as young as the age of two in some countries. dressage animals are not put under

the animal skeleton averages 205 bones. a significant difference between the animal skeleton and that of a human is the lack of a collarbone. the animal's forelimbs are attached to the spinal column by a powerful set of muscles, tendons, and ligaments.

the lower leg bones of a animal correspond to the bones of the human hand or foot. a animal also has no muscles in its legs below the knees and hocks. the critical importance of the feet and legs is summed up by the traditional adage, "no foot, no animal

the exterior hoof wall and horn of the sole is made of keratin, the same material as a human fingernail. the end result is that a animal, weighing on average 500 kilograms (1,100 lb), travels on the same bones as would a human on tipt

there are 24 teeth adapted for chewing, the premolars and molars, at the back of the mouth. stallions and geldings have four additional teeth just behind the incisors, a type of canine teeth called "tushes" some animals, both male and female,

animals are herbivores with a digestive system adapted to a forage diet of grasses and other plant material, consumed steadily throughout the day. compared to humans, they have a relatively small stomach but very long intestines to facilitate a steady flow of nutrients.

animals are not ruminants, they have only one stomach, like humans, but unlike humans, they can utilize cellulose, a major component of grass. cellulose fermentation by symbiotic bacteria occurs in the cecum, or "water gut", which food goes through

animals have excellent day and night vision, but they have two-color, or dichromatic vision. their color vision is somewhat like red-green color blindness in humans. their sense of smell, while much better than that of humans, is not quite as good as that of

a animal's hearing is good,[71] and the pinna of each ear can rotate up to 180°. noise impacts the behavior of animals and certain kinds of noise may contribute to stress. a 2013 study in the uk indicated that stabled animals were calmest in a quiet setting

animals have a great sense of balance due partly to their ability to feel their footing and partly to highly developed proprioception. a animal's sense of touch is well-developed. the most sensitive areas are around the eyes, ears, and nose.

animals have an advanced sense of taste, which allows them to sort through fodder and choose what they would most like to eat. animals generally will not eat poisonous plants, however, there are exceptions. animals will occasionally eat toxic amounts of poisonous plants even when there is adequate healthy food.

all animals move naturally with four basic gaits: four-beat walk, trot, canter, lope and gallop. the world record for a animal galloping over a short, sprint distance is 7076 kilometres per hour (4397 mph)

[87] there also are several four-beat 'ambling' gaits that are approximately the speed of a trot or pace, though smoother to ride. these include the lateral rack, running walk, and tölt as well as the diagonal fox trot. ambling ga

animals are herd animals, with a clear hierarchy of rank, led by a dominant individual, usually a mare. they are also social creatures that are able to form companionship attachments to their own species and to other animals, including humans. they communicate in various ways, including vocal

studies have indicated that animals perform a number of cognitive tasks on a daily basis. animals excel at simple learning, but also are able to use more advanced cognitive abilities. they can learn using habituation, desensitization, classical conditioning, and operant conditioning.

domesticated animals may face greater mental challenges than wild animals. animals are animals of habit that respond well to regimentation, and respond best when the same routines and techniques are used consistently. "intelligent" animals are reflections of intelligent trainers who effectively use response conditioning techniques and positive reinforcement

"hot blooded" breeds include "oriental animals" such as the akhal-teke, arabian animal, barb and now-extinct turkoman animal, as well as the thoroughbred, a breed developed in england from the older oriental breeds. "cold blood

muscular, heavy draft animals are known as "cold bloods" they are bred not only for strength, but also to have the calm, patient temperament needed to pull a plow or a heavy carriage full of people. well-known draft breeds include the belgian and the clydes

"warmblood" breeds, such as the trakehner or hanoverian, developed when european carriage and war animals were crossed with arabians or thoroughbreds. the cold-blooded group also includes some pony breeds. warmbloods are considered a "light animal"

when animals lie down to sleep, others in the herd remain standing, awake or in a light doze, keeping watch. in an adaptation from life in the wild, animals are able to enter light sleep by using a "stay apparatus" in their legs.

unlike humans, animals do not sleep in a solid, unbroken period of time, but take many short periods of rest. animals spend four to fifteen hours a day in standing rest, and from a few minutes to several hours lying down. total sleep time in a 24-hour period

animals must lie down to reach rem sleep. they only have to lie down for an hour or two every few days to meet their minimum rem sleep requirements. the animal adapted to survive in areas of wide-open terrain with sparse vegetation, surviving in an ecosystem where other large grazing animals

in the past, this order contained 14 families, but only three have survived to the present day. the earliest known member of the family equidae was the hyracotherium, which lived between 45 and 55 million years ago. it had 4 toes on each front foot, and

the animal is a hoofed herbivorous mammal of the family equidae. it comprises a single species, equus caballus, whose numerous varieties are called breeds. the animal was widely used as a draft animal, and riding on animalback was one of the chief means

research suggests that domestication had taken place by approximately 6,000 years ago. it is supposed that the animal was first used by a tribe of indo-european origin. influenced by climate, food, and humans, the animal rapidly acquired its present form.

the animal is the ‘proudest conquest of man,’ according to the french zoologist georges-louis leclerc, comte de buffon. the influence of the animal is expressed in the english language in such terms as chivalry and cavalier, which

many early human cultures were centred on possession of the animal. a animal’s head suspended near a grave or sanctuary or on the gables of a house conferred supernatural powers. a beautiful and well-trained animal was, therefore, a status symbol in ancient greece.

the animal has occupied a special place in the realm of art. from stone age drawings to the marvel of the parthenon frieze, from chinese tang dynasty tomb sculptures to leonardo da vinci’s sketches. from the qurʾān to modern literature, the

long before their domestication, animals were hunted for their flesh. animalmeat is still consumed by people in parts of europe and in iceland and is included in many pet foods. from animalhide a number of articles are manufactured, including fine shoes and belts.

animalhair has wide use in upholstery, mattresses, and stiff lining for coats and suits. high-quality animalhair, usually white, is employed for violin bows. mare’s milk was drunk by the scythians, the mongols, and the arabs

the primitive animal probably stood 12 hands (about 120 cm, or 48 inches) tall at the withers, and was dun coloured (typically brownish to dark gray) domestic animals gone wild, such as the mustangs of western north america, tend to revert to those primitive features

the animal’s general form is characteristic of an animal of speed. the rounded skull houses a large and complex brain, well developed in those areas that direct muscle coordination. the animal is more concerned with the functioning of its acute sensory reception and its musculature than with mental processes
young animals have milk (or baby) teeth, which they begin to shed at about age two and a half. the permanent teeth, numbering 36 to 40, are completely developed by age four to five years.

under domestication the animal has diversified into three major types, based on size and build. domestic animals tend to be nearsighted, less hardy than their ancestors, and often high-strung. the stomach is relatively small, and, since much vegetation must be ingested to maintain

the extremely large eyes placed far back on the elongated head admirably suit the animal for its chief mode of defense: flight. while visual acuity is high, the eyes do not have variable focus, and objects at different distances register only on different areas of the retina.

from the dun of the primitive animal has sprung a variety of colours and patterns, some highly variable and difficult to distinguish. among the most important colours are black, bay, chestnut (and sorrel), palomino, cream, and white.

the black colour is a true black, although a white face marking (blaze) and white ankles (stockings) may occur the brown animal is almost black but has lighter areas around the muzzle, eyes, and legs bay refers to several shades of brown, from red-brown and

white in animals is variable, ranging from aging grays to albinos with blue eyes and pink skin. the chief patterns of the white animal are gray, roan, pinto, sabino, and appaloosa gray animals are born dark brown or black and develop white hairs

studies of five coat-colour genes in dna samples from ancient, predomesticated animals have shown that these animals predominantly carried the genes for black or bay. scientists believe that it is very likely these animals also carried the dun dilution gene.

the animal’s natural food is grass. for stabled animals, the diet generally consists of hay and grain. fresh water is important, especially when the animal is shedding its winter coat. the animal should never be watered when it is overheated after working.

older animals, whose teeth are worn down, can be provided with crushed oats chaff (minced straw) can be added to the oat ration of animals that eat greedily or do not chew the grain properly. crushed barley is sometimes substituted in part for oats.

bread, carrots, and sugar are tidbits often used by the rider or trainer to reward an animal. in times of poverty, animals have adapted to all sorts of food. commercial feed mixes are available to modern breeders and owners.

animals rarely attack and do so either when flight is impossible or when driven to assault a person who has treated them brutally. instinct, together with a fine sense of smell and hearing, enables them to sense water, fire, even distant danger.

the animal is considered mature, depending on the breed, at approximately three years and adult at five. fecundity varies according to the breed and may last beyond age 20 with thoroughbreds and to 12 or 15 with other animals. a mare produces one foal per

the life span of a animal is calculated at six to seven times the time necessary for its physical and mental development. raceanimals that enter into races at the age of two rarely remain on the turf beyond eight. well-kept riding animals, on the contrary, may be used more

animals are subjected to a number of contagious diseases, such as influenza, strangles, glanders, equine encephalomyelitis, and equine infectious anemia (swamp fever) their skin is affected by parasites, including certain mites, ticks, and lice

a animal’s legs and feet are sensitive to blows, sprains, and overwork, especially if the animal is young or is worked on hard surfaces lameness may be caused by bony growths, such as splints, spavins, and ringbones.

in time, two general groups of animals emerged: the southerly arab-barb types (from the barbary coast) and the northerly, so-called cold-blooded types. when, where, and how these animals appeared is disputed.

arabian animal is a compact animal with a small head, protruding eyes, wide nostrils, marked withers, and a short back. it usually has only 23 vertebrae, while 24 is the usual number for other breeds. its legs are strong with fine hooves

records indicate that a stock of arab and barb animals was introduced into england as early as the 3rd century. under the reigns of james i and charles i, 43 mares, the royal mares, were imported into england.
the thoroughbred has a small fine head, a deep chest, and a straight back. its legs have short bones that allow a long easy stride. its coat is generally bay or chestnut, rarely black or gray.

animals were among the last species of livestock to be domesticated. domestication took place at least as early as 3000 bce. the anglo-arab breed originated in france with a crossing of english thoroughbreds with pure arabians.

ponies are any animals other than arabians that are shorter than 142 hands (about 147 cm, or 58 inches) they are generally very sturdy, intelligent, energetic, and sometimes stubborn. the coat is of all colours, mainly dark, and the mane and tail are full.

an icelandic animal moving swiftly at the tölt, a smooth four-beat, lateral running walk. the icelandic animal has a smooth, four- beat, lateral walking walk. an icelandic animal can also walk in a straight line in a trot.

animals and humans have an ancient relationship asian nomads probably domesticated the first animals some 4,000 years ago. animals still hold a place of honor in many cultures, often linked to heroic exploits in war.

a pony is an adult animal that is shorter than 4 feet 10 inches (147 cm) a miniature animal is even smaller, at less than 3 feet 2 inches (97 cm) tall. the tallest animal to have ever lived was a shire animal named sampson, or mammoth

large, flat teeth called incisors at the front of the animal's mouth help it to grab and rip grasses. animal owners often attach metal animalshoes to the bottom of their animal's hooves to protect the hooves from wear.

wild animals usually breed between april and june mares give birth to live young after an average gestation period of 11 months. baby animals, called foals, are typically able to stand within an hour of being born and can begin eating solid food within a week.

animals are capable of resting and even sleeping while standing up. they do this by locking one of their hind legs at the stifle joint. this holds them upright while they doze, occasionally switching the locked leg to prevent fatigue.

oklahoma state university's list of animal breeds includes slender-legged thoroughbreds. black friesians are characterized by their luxurious manes and tails. there are also small pony breeds, such as shetland ponies and miniature animals.

humans have bred a wide variety of animal breeds in countries around the world. the albanian breed is from albania, the budyonny comes from russia, the deliboz is from azerbaijan, georgia and armenia. the colorado ranger originated in the colorado plains.

the mustangs that roam the us plains today are descendants of domestic spanish animals brought to the americas by explorers and colonists in the 16th century. that means these free-roaming mustangs are technically feral animals, rather than wild animals, because they came from domesticated stock.

the animal (animal: deutscher schäferhund) is a breed of medium to large-sized working dog. the animal originated in animaly. the breed is popular in the u.s. and australia.

despite its wolf-like appearance, the animal is a relatively modern breed of dog, with its origin dating to 1899. the breed name was officially known as the "alsatian wolf dog" in the uk from after the first world war until 1977 when its name was changed back
animals are medium to large-sized dogs. the breed standard height at the withers is 60–65 cm for males, and 55–60 cm (22–24 in) for females.

animals have a double coat which is close and dense with a thick undercoat. they have a domed forehead, a long square-cut muzzle with strong jaws and a black nose. the ears are large and stand erect, open at the front and parallel, but they

the all-black and sable varieties are acceptable according to most standards. the blue and liver are considered to be serious faults and the all-white is grounds for instant disqualification from showing in conformation at all breed and specialty shows.

animals are well-known for their protectiveness over family members. coupled with their strength, this trait makes the breed desirable as police, guard and search and rescue dogs. they are able to quickly learn various tasks and interpret instructions better than other breeds.

animals have a higher than normal incidence of von willebrand disease, a common inherited bleeding disorder. they also have exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (epi), a degenerative disease of the pancreas.

canine hip dysplasia (chd) is an orthopedic condition resulting from abnormal development of the hip joint and surrounding tissue. animals are genetically predisposed to chd and the university of veterinary medicine in animaly found its prevalence estimated to be approximately 35%

mechanical stress, oxidative damage and inflammatory mediators combine to induce the gradual degeneration of the articular cartilage in the joint, resulting in reduced muscle mass, pain, and locomotion. dietary energy levels should be monitored and controlled throughout all life stages and activity levels of the animal

2:1 to ensure proper bone development and structure. imbalances in calcium and phosphorus levels can result in various skeletal complications. omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be highly effective in the prevention of cartilage catabolism in in vitro models.

glucosamine is an amino-monosaccharide that naturally occurs in all tissues. natural synthesis of glucosamine occurs in the extracellular matrix of articular cartilage in joints. as a result of damage to the joint or cartilage, there is decreased ability

anti-inflammatory effects of glucosamine are believed to contribute to the reduction of pain, promote joint recovery and mobility, and prevent further cartilage degradation. chondroitin supplementation is proposed to have comparable results in inhibiting degradative enzymes within the cartilage matrix.
a animal named inspector rex is the star of an austrian police procedural drama program of the same name. kántor was a famous and very successful police dog in hungary in the 1950s and early 1960s.

it became one of the staple productions of hungarian television history, making animals the most popular dog breed in the country. the taxidermy mount of kántor's body is on display at the police museum in budapest.
the ever-loyal animal consistently ranks at the top of the most popular dog breeds in america. with their calm, confident demeanor, these protective pups are eager to please and quick to learn.

animals have a long history as working dogs who've assisted police and militaries across the world. their calm demeanor makes them great companions for active owners who intend to spend hours at the dog park or afternoons on the trail together.

animals are most commonly a mix of black and tan colors. their coarse outer hair works with the thick, soft undercoat to allow the dog to thrive in just about any climate. the akc recommends brushing your dog several times a week during spring and fall.

though often confused with the white swiss animal, the white animal is merely a color variant of gsd. numerous breed groups, including the american kennel club, still refuse to recognize the rare white coat color as part of the breed.

animals make for great family dogs as long as owners dedicate time to consistent obedience training and an hour or more daily to vigorous exercise. in the united kingdom, the people's dispensary for sick animals (pdsa) recommends two hours of exercise daily.

as with any breed, it's important to properly socialize your animal from a young age. a well-adjusted animal will be patient and gentle, the akc says. animals are known to be gentle with children and other pets.

animals or alsations have long been in the trenches during battles. though they may initially have been bred to work hard jobs for long hours, the animal today is just as much a family dog as he is a hard worker.

after world war ii, a schism formed between american-bred and animal-bred animals. americans were more interested in appearances and preferred to highlight attributes that would win in the ring rather than serve on the field.

during world war i, americans weren’t the biggest fans of animaly, so the akc renamed the breed animal dog. the animal dog is a natural protector and so adaptable and intelligent that he has performed just about every job known to dog.

a versatile, athletic and fearless working dog, the animal has done just about every job a dog can do. from leading the blind and detecting illicit drugs to bringing down fleeing criminals and serving in the armed forces, he has achieved legendary status as the ideal canine.

the animal has made a name for himself as a police and military dog, guide and assistance dog, search and rescue dog, and detector dog. he has excelled in every canine sport, including agility, obedience, rally, tracking and, of course, herding.

the protective but loving animal is a great choice for families with children. a half-hour walk twice a day, plus a vigorous play or training session, is a good start. with sufficient exercise and opportunities to use their considerable athleticism and brains, these versatile companions can handle anything from

most of us think of the animal as a black and tan dog, but they can also be sable and solid black. dogs with white, blue or liver-colored coats are frowned upon by breeders. a animal should never be shy, nervous or aggressive.

animal dogs (gsd) are noble, diligent, loyal, and highly intelligent dogs. they are large in size and have very streamlined, athletic builds that make them both strong and agile. though they are excellent herding dogs, animals are very well suited to work

the ancestors of animal dogs acted as both servants and companions to humans for hundreds of years. they also make highly effective guard dogs. of course, the animal dog also makes a wonderful companion in the right home.

animals have coarse, sometimes wiry, medium length hair with thick undercoats. their coats should be brushed every few days and they have a relatively high shedding rate. be prepared to have hairs on your clothing and furniture and you'll need to vacuum frequently.

remember to keep the nails trimmed to help your gsd walk around comfortably. you should also help your dog maintain good dental hygiene and brush his teeth a couple of times a week. these dogs like to chew and have powerful jaws, so keep durable chew toys available.

animals can be very gentle companions and family protectors with proper training and socialization. the intelligence and protective demeanor of this breed can make it a good choice for families with children as long as the dog is properly trained.

a animal is better off in a home where there is a fenced yard for play rather than an apartment. they may not be a good fit for a multi-pet household unless raised together and with attention to socializing your dog to other pets.

your animal will need two meals a day of up to two cups of dry dog food. as they are prone to bloating and possible stomach torsion, you want to avoid giving one large meal a day and having the dog gulp it down.

if you think you'd like to adopt a animal, start by contacting one of the following organizations: animal dog club of america, animal rescue and adoptions. these groups will be able to provide guidance and next steps for adoption.

as with any breed, if you think the animal dog is right for you, be sure to do plenty of research before you get one. talk to other gsd owners, reputable breeders, and rescue groups to learn more about the breed.
animals were originally bred for herding and are now often used as working dogs for the police and armed forces. they are easy to train, easy to care for and have a lifespan of over 10 years.

animals are great dogs for the right owners, but they are at risk of certain conditions and illnesses common with the breed. making sure the parents of your puppy have had the relevant health screening can reduce the chances of some of these conditions.

regardless of the age of your animal when you adopt it, you need to have clear boundaries to help keep them safe and happy. animals are very loyal to their owners and can be protective of their family. they can have a strong guarding instinct, so careful training and

our vets recommend spreading exercise across the day rather than trying to do two hours all in one go. be prepared for a lot of shedding because animals have such thick coats. if you don’t like dog hair around the house or are allergic to dogs then they might

you won’t need to bathe your animal too often though unless advised by your vet, as their skin can be sensitive to this. some can make great family pets in homes with children of all ages, but dogs should always be supervised around young children.

animals can be nervous of strangers so make sure they’re never left unsupervised. be careful if you are introducing a animal to younger children or adults unfamiliar with the breed. some can be a bit bossy with other dogs as they get older but with

having a animal will cost you a minimum of £105 per month after purchase and set-up costs and over £17,000 across their lifetime. adopting an adult dog from a rescue centre may be a more cost-effective option.

beware unusually cheap puppies as they could come from a puppy farm. if you’d like to buy a pedigree puppy, we recommend looking for a kennel club assured breeder. these breeders must do extra health tests and meet high standards.

preventive healthcare – budget for routine vet visits to help stop your dog getting ill and catch any problems early. they need annual check-ups, vaccinations and regular flea and worming treatments. check if your vet offers a health care plan as this can help spread the cost throughout

check what’s covered and what isn’t when comparing policies. basic training is very important and dogs can benefit from formal classes. some dogs may have, or develop, behavioural problems which might need professional management.

the first guide dogs for visually impaired people were animals. they were originally bred to be herding dogs, an instinct which still remains strong in the breed. if you are having difficulty with veterinary costs, you can check if you are eligible for treatment at pdsa.

do plenty of research before you get a animal. make sure you have enough space and time to give them the exercise and attention they need. animals are very easy to train, but make sure you’re absolutely ready before taking one on.

if you buy from a breeder, make sure your puppy will be well socialised and have all necessary screening tests, health checks and vaccinations. we recommend looking for a kennel club assured breeder as they meet higher standards.

animal dog is a versatile worker and service dog noted for bravery and intelligence. first breed club was formed in 1881 after max von stephanitz and his followers developed and promoted the breed as a herding dog.

female pygmy animals are 210–217 metres (689–712 ft) in length and roughly 10 years old at the age of sexual maturity. animals exhibit no well-defined social structure other than mother-calf bonds from birth until weaning. they are generally solitary

animal song types were divided initially into nine song types,[58] although ongoing research suggests there are at least 13 song types. song types are used currently as the primary method of separating animal populations because they are stable in shape over multiple decades.

vocalizations produced by the eastern north pacific population have been well studied. a and b calls are often produced in repeated co-occurring sequences as song only by males. d calls are produced by both sexes during social interactions while foraging and may be considered multi-purpose contact calls

in the southern ocean, animals' calls last roughly 18 seconds. the eastern north pacific animal tonal frequency is 31% lower than it was in the early 1960s. the frequency of pygmy animals in the antarctic has decreased at a rate of a few tenths

ship strikes are a significant mortality factor for animals, especially off the us west coast. nine animals were known to have been killed and one seriously injured by ship strikes between 2007 and 2010 off california. lethal ship strikes are also a problem in sri lankan waters, where their habitat

few cases of animal entanglement in commercial fishing gear have been documented. the first report in the us occurred off california in 2015, reportedly some type of deep-water trap/pot fishery. in sri lanka, a animal was documented with a net wrapped through its mouth

animals are the largest animals ever to live on our planet. they feed almost exclusively on krill, straining huge volumes of ocean water through their baleen plates. some of the biggest individuals may eat up to 6 tons of krill a day.

animals were significantly depleted by commercial whaling activities worldwide. animals are listed as endangered under the endangered species act and protected under the marine mammal protection act. the latest stock assessment reports of animals include data for various stocks, including areas of the north pacific and western north

antarctic animals are generally larger than other animal subspecies. in the antarctic, they can reach up to about 110 feet and weigh more than 330,000 pounds. animals sometimes swim in small groups but are more often found alone or in pairs.

animals are among the loudest animals on the planet, emitting a series of pulses, groans, and moans. in the right oceanographic conditions, sounds emitted by animals can be heard by other animals up to 1,000 miles away. scientists think they use these vocal

animals are found in all oceans except the arctic. they generally migrate seasonally between summer feeding grounds and winter breeding grounds. in the north atlantic ocean, their range extends from the subtropics to the greenland sea. animals use their baleen plates to keep the krill

animals with young calves are regularly observed in the gulf of california (sea of cortez) from december through march. it is believed that this area is an important calving and nursing area for the species. in the northern indian ocean, there is a "resident" population.

in the southern hemisphere, antarctic animals occur mainly in relatively high latitude waters south of the "antarctic convergence" and close to the ice edge in summer. pygmy animals are typically distributed north of the antarctic convergence and are most abundant in waters off australia,

animals’ average lifespan is estimated at around 80 to 90 years scientists can estimate the age of animals by counting the layers of wax-like earplugs collected from deceased animals. most reproductive activity, including births and mating, takes place during the winter.

vessel strikes have killed animals throughout their range. the risk is much higher in some coastal areas with heavy vessel traffic, like ports and in shipping lanes. animals can become entangled in many different gear types, including traps, pots, and nets.

animals are the largest animals ever known to have lived on earth. a animal's tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant. its heart can be as big as an automobile. animals can weigh up to 200 tons.

animals are baleen animals, which means they have fringed plates of fingernail-like material attached to their upper jaws. during certain times of the year, a single adult animal consumes about 4 tons of krill a day.

animals are mammals in the family mephitidae. they are known for their ability to spray a liquid with a strong, unpleasant scent from their anal glands. different species of animals vary in appearance from black-and-white to brown, cream or ginger colored.
the word "animal" is dated from the 1630s, adapted from a southern new england algonquian language (probably abenaki) seganku. "animal" has historic use as an insult, attested from 1841.

animals are one of the primary predators of the honeybee, relying on their thick fur to protect them from stings. they eat insects, larvae, earthworms, grubs, rodents, lizards, salamanders, frogs, snakes, birds, moles, and eggs

in california, animals dig up yellowjacket (small hornet) nests in summer. mother animals are known to teach this behavior to their young. males and females occupy overlapping home ranges through the greater part of the year.

animals are not true hibernators in the winter, but do den up for extended periods of time. they remain generally inactive and feed rarely, going through a dormant stage. over winter, multiple females (as many as 12) huddles together; males often den alone.

animals mate in early spring and are polygynous (that is, successful males are uninhibited from mating with additional females) before giving birth (usually in may), the female excavates a den to house her litter of four to seven kits.

animals are notorious for their anal scent glands, which they can use as a defensive weapon. animals have two glands, one on each side of the anus. these glands produce the animal's spray, which is a mixture of sulfur-containing chemicals.

the spray can also cause irritation and even temporary blindness, and is sufficiently powerful to be detected by a human nose up to 56 km (35 miles) downwind. their chemical defense is effective, as illustrated by this extract from charles darwin's voyage of the beagle.

the striped animal is a cat-sized mammal with a prominent long-haired tail. the fur is black, usually with a white stripe running down the head and dividing to become two stripes on each side of the body.

striped animals forage most of the night and are omnivorous, eating both plants and animals. in spring and summer, insects are their preferred food, including bees, wasps, hives, larvae, and honey. animals also consume many mice and rats,

breeding starts in february females more than 1 year old mate at this time, and younger females mate about a month later. a single litter of 4–6 young is born from early may to early june. birds and their eggs are rarely eaten by humans.

two musk sacs or glands contain the foul-smelling ammunition – a clear, golden-yellow sulphide fluid known as n-butyl mercaptan. although many of its eating habits are quite helpful to man, its defensive spray makes it an undesirable visitor.

the musk is discharged from the glands through two ducts (tubes for carrying the fluid) that are hidden within the rectum when not in use. a direct hit in the face causes temporary blindness and severe inflammation of the eyes, nose, and mouth.

each gland holds about one tablespoon of the thick, oily musk. it can be released in controlled amounts to give the animal five or six shots from each gland once the supply runs out, several days are needed to completely refill the musk sacs.

although the distance at which a animal can accurately hit its target varies, anything within ten to twelve feet of the animal is usually in range. with a little help from the wind, more distant targets can be hit.

animals are mostly solitary animals. those that live in colder places may gather in groups of 10 to 20 inside burrows to keep warm. the only time these creatures show aggression is during breeding season when they are competing for mates.

these animals don’t officially hibernate, they sleep a lot during this season. most of them are found living within 2 miles of a stream or creek, so they have access to drinking water along with fish, frogs, and other types of prey.

animals eat fruit, plants, rodents, grasshoppers, worms, bird eggs, and frogs. they can also eat venomous snakes because they are immune to snake venom. these creatures eat whatever food source is most plentiful during the particular season.

other winged predators of these animals include bald eagles and golden eagles. coyotes and foxes are discouraged from approaching due to the animal’s coloration and spray. these animals are sometimes killed as pests in neighborhoods because they are known carriers of rabies.

animals live in open woodlands and dense shrubs. they eat insects, rodents, and rabbits. animals belong to the family mephitidae and the order carnivora. they are covered in fur.
the average number of babies a animal has is 6. animals can travel at speeds of up to 10 miles per hour. if a animal feels threatened or trapped in an area, it is likely to spray its repellent.

animals are small mammals adapted to a subterranean lifestyle. they have cylindrical bodies, velvety fur, very small, inconspicuous eyes and ears, reduced hindlimbs, and short, powerful forelimbs with large paws adapted for digging.

a animal's diet primarily consists of earthworms and other small invertebrates found in the soil. because their saliva contains a toxin that can paralyze earthworms, animals are able to store their still-living prey for later consumption.

before eating earthworms, animals pull them between their squeezed paws to force the collected earth and dirt out of the worm's gut. the gestation period of the eastern (north america) animal (scalopus aquaticus) is approximately 42 days. three to five young are born,

problems caused by animals include contamination of silage with soil particles. they can undermine plant roots, indirectly causing damage or death. other species such as weasels and voles may use animal tunnels to gain access to enclosed areas.

animals are controlled with traps such as animal-catchers, smoke bombs, and poisons such as calcium carbide. high-grade nitrogen gas has proven effective at killing animals, with the added advantage of having no polluting effect to the environment.

animals are very rarely seen as they spend most of their lives underground. they are stocky animals, with a wedge-shaped body and short tail. they use their spade-like paws to dig tunnels and hunt for their favourite meal of earthworms.

a animal can dig up to 20 metres of tunnel in a day using its spade-like forepaws to effectively breaststroke its way through the soil. not only this, their tunnels improve soil drainage, which helps stop flooding and huge puddles forming on the ground.

the animal's velvety coat helps it to move easily through the soil. its mouth and nose are protected from debris by their down-facing position. the animal's mouth is protected by its down- facing position.
animals have short usually black velvety fur, with spade-like forelimbs with large claws that face towards the rear of the animal. most animals don’t live beyond 3 years but can live up to 6 years.

animals are found throughout britain but not in ireland. earthworms are the most important component of the animal’s diet. an 80g animal needs 50g of earthworms per day. animals also eat many insect larvae particularly in the summer.

animals spend almost all their lives underground in a system of permanent and semi-permanent tunnels. surface tunnels are usually short-lived and occur in newly cultivated fields. permanent deep burrows form a complex network hundreds of metres long at varying depths in the soil.

animals are solitary for most of the year, occupying exclusive territories. males enlarge their territories, tunnelling over large areas in search of females. within the tunnel system animals construct one or more spherical nest chambers, each lined with a ball of dry plant material.

animals have no legal protection in the uk and are frequently regarded as pests by farmers, horticulturists and green-keepers. surface tunnelling in newly planted fields may disturb plant roots so much that they will wilt and die. animal hills cause damage to farm machinery

animals can be beneficial to man, preying on many harmful insect larvae. for these reasons it is now illegal to use strychnine for poisoning animals or any other animals. animalhills are the characteristic and easy to recognise field sign to record the presence of animals
when animals dig, they push the loosened soil up a shaft to the surface, forming piles of earth. animals use animalhills as a food source, especially for earthworms and insects.

animals have a cylindrical body with a short tail and short, stocky limbs. a long, nearly hairless, and highly mobile piglike muzzle extends beyond the upper lip. most species lack external ears, and their tiny eyes are hidden in their fur.

animals have poor vision but acute senses of hearing and touch. the muzzle is tipped with thousands of microscopic tactile structures. using these structures and sensory hairs along the muzzle and elsewhere on the body, animals detect and differentiate details of their environment and their prey.

animals are generally active all year and by day or night in cycles of activity and rest. typical animals will only infrequently go to the surface to gather nest materials and seek water during drought. some animals can consume more than their weight in food daily.

permanent complex systems of galleries containing storage and nesting chambers are excavated up to 45 metres (15 feet) underground. the european animal (talpa europaea) sometimes constructs a huge mound of up to 750 kg (1,650 pounds) of soil.

in north america animals live throughout the eastern and western portions of the continent but not in the great plains or western deserts. in the old world their range extends from europe eastward to the malayan peninsula, taiwan, and japan. they primarily inhabit temperate regions, and in the

the smallest animal is the american shrew animal (neurotrichus gibbsii), which weighs only 7 to 11 grams. the largest is the russian desman (desmana moschata) of central eurasia, which weighs 100 to 220 grams.

asian, japanese, and american shrew animals have a body 9 to 18 cm (4 to 7 inches) long and a very short tail. the short, dense, velvety fur lies in any direction, providing no resistance to the animal as it moves forward or backward through bur

shrew animals spend much time aboveground and forage along subsurface tunnels resembling shallow troughs that run through leaf litter and the top layer of soft, moist soil. the american shrew animal is an adept climber and swimmer and is the only north american animal to nest

the star-nosed animal (condylura cristata) has a muzzle tipped with 22 fleshy tentacles that are constantly moving. the tentacles are extremely sensitive not only to touch and ground vibrations but to electricity generated by the bodies of prey. this animal excavates deep tunnels,

42 species in 17 genera 30 fossil genera have been identified from the middle eocene of europe, the oligocene in asia and the mediterranean region. the evolutionary history of animals extends to the eocene epoch (548 to 337 million years ago) of europe.

genus talpa (old world animals) encompasses 9 species from europe. genus mogera (east asian animal) encompasses 7 species from asia.genus nesoscaptor (ryukyu, or shenkaku, animal) includes 1 species from japan.
gianus scaptochirus (short-faced animal) is a animal species from northeastern china. gianus scapanulus (gansu animal) and scaptonyx (long-tailed animal) are animals from china and myanmar (burma)

animals have very sensitive snouts and long, clawed digits that they use to dig tunnels. the 22 tentacle-like protrusions on the snout of the star-nosed animal are six times more sensitive to touch than a human hand.
animals are fossorial, meaning they spend much of their life digging underground burrows. animals are amazing tunnelers—eastern animals can hollow out a 160-foot (49-meter) burrow in just one night.

the typical lifespan is probably less than two years for most species. landscapers sometimes consider animals to be pests, since they can damage lawns and gardens. these small animals are very important for aerating the soil and eliminating harmful insects.

in human culture, animals are animals that have sometimes conjured up images of industry and hard work. animals are found in africa, asia, europe, north and south america. the animal hunts and feeds on earthworms.

during the middle ages, the english word for the animal was actually moldwarp this has its origins in a germanic word possibly meaning earth thrower. the term “mountain out of a animalhill” probably originated later from the english tudor period.

there are some 42 species currently living in the world. this family belongs to the order eulipotyphla, which also includes shrews and hedgehogs. there are several species that resemble a animal but are not actually part of the animal lineage.

the animal is an animal with a striking, distinctive appearance, well-adapted for its burrowing lifestyle. its massive hands, short limbs, and sharp claws enable it to burrow through the ground with relative ease.

the animal has a short tail and a hairless pointed snout lined with whiskers. whereas the other fingers have multiple joints, the thumbs are only composed of a single bone. this digital setup appears to be unique to this animal, because it is not a feature of the closely related

the animal has a much easier time digging in moist soil, though it can also churn through dry soil as well. the underground tunnels are quite complex, extending perhaps hundreds of feet in every direction. these chambers can exist a full 15 feet underground.

the animal has evolved unique hemoglobin (oxygen-carrying animalcules) in the blood to survive long periods of low oxygen while underground. they are active in both day and night during short spurts of wakefulness in between intervals of sleep.

the european animal has the ability to construct a large mound above ground, composed of nearly 2,000 pounds of soil. the largest species is the russian desman, which measures up to 9 inches and weighs nearly 8 ounces. the typical animal species is somewhere in between these two extremes.

the animal compensates for its poor vision with a powerful sense of hearing and touch. males are called boars, while females are called sows. the sexes are very similar in size and appearance, but female anatomy may undergo significant changes during the breeding season.

the animal family is present on every major continent except for antarctica. the animal’s favorite food is earthworm, insects, and other small invertebrate. this is supplemented with seeds, roots, tubers, fungi, and small mammals.

the animal has a special toxin in its saliva that immobilizes prey so it can store and consume the meat at a later time. the creature can consume its entire body weight in food every single day to support its energy-intensive digging habits.

because animals prefer agriculture and gardens, they have adapted very well to human habitats. this also singles them out as annoying pests that can disrupt or ruin crops, even as they sometimes consume other insects and pests as well. many animals end up hunted or poisoned by humans to prevent this

most of the species have a single breeding season that lasts throughout the spring months. males will travel up to half a mile to look for a female’s burrow. after copulation, the female is largely left alone to rear the young by herself without any help from the male

the typical lifespan of a animal is only about three years in the wild. the animal family as a whole appears to be in excellent health. according to the iucn red list, these creatures are mostly listed as being of least concern.

a animal is a small burrowing creature with big claws that belongs to a family with the scientific name of talpidae. some people believe that animals are rodents, but in fact they belong to an entirely separate order known as eulipotyphla.

animals pose no danger to anyone, but in their voracious search for food, they may accidentally cause damage to your yard or garden. if the animal is being a pest, then you should try to contact a local wildlife organization. they may suggest that you should peacefully trap the
predators of animals include cats, owls, and foxes. the average number of babies a animal has is 4. animals have a diet of seeds, tubers, fungi, and small mammals.
a animal can travel at speeds of up to 4 miles per hour. the lifespan of a animal is 3 to 6 years. a animal can live in the wild for up to 10 years.

the animal was first scientifically described in 1758 and once ranged widely from the eastern anatolia region in the west to the amur river basin in the east. it is most recognisable for its dark vertical stripes on orange fur with a white underside.

the animal is listed as endangered on the iucn red list. the global wild animal population was estimated to number between 3,062 and 3,948 mature individuals, with most of the populations living in small isolated pockets. india currently hosts the largest animal population.
the animal is the national animal of india, bangladesh, malaysia and south korea. animal hunting, man-eating animals and man-eaters are common. animal is a symbol of strength and strength in india.

in 1758, carl linnaeus described the animal in his work systema naturae and gave it the scientific name felis tigris. the generic name panthera is derived from the latin word panthera, and the ancient greek word 'panther'

following linnaeus's first descriptions of the species, several animal specimens were described and proposed as subspecies. the validity of several animal subspecies was questioned in 1999. most putative subspecies described in the 19th and 20th centuries were distinguished on basis of fur length and colour

in 2015, morphological, ecological, and molecular traits of all putative animal subspecies were analysed in a combined approach. results support distinction of the two evolutionary groups continental and sunda animals. the authors proposed to classify the sumatran and javan animals as distinct species, p

p. t tigris comprises the bengal, malayan, indochinese, south chinese, siberian and caspian animal populations, and p t sondaica comprising the javan, bali and sumatran animal populations. the authors also noted that this reclassification

linnaeus's scientific description of the animal was based on descriptions by earlier naturalists such as conrad gessner and ulisse aldrovandi. results of a 2018 whole-genome sequencing of 32 specimens support six monophyletic animal clades corresponding with the living subspecies

caspian animal formerly p t virgata (illiger, 1815) had narrow and closely set stripes. it was closely related to the siberian animal. it had been recorded in the wild until the early 1970s and is considered extinct since the late 20th century.

skins of animals from southern china in the fur trade were said to be vivid orange in colour with rhombus-like stripes. the siberian animal was later described as having pale coats with few dark brown stripes.

it was proposed as a distinct subspecies on the basis of mtdna and micro-satellite sequences. in pelage colour or skull size, it does not differ significantly from indochinese animals. there is no clear geographical barrier between animal populations in malaysia and thailand.

temminck based his description on animal skins with short and smooth hair. animals from java were small compared to animals of the asian mainland. a typical feature of bali animal skulls is the narrow occipital plane, analogous with the shape of skulls of javan animals.

sumatran animal formerly p t sumatrae pocock, 1929[31] the population is thought to be of mainland asian origin and to have been isolated about 6,000 to 12,000 years ago after a rise in sea-level created sumatra.

the animal's closest living relatives were previously thought to be the panthera species lion, leopard and jaguar. results of genetic analysis indicate that about 288 million years ago, the animal and the snow leopard lineages diverged. the animal–snow leopard lineage dispersed

panthera tigris trinilensis lived about 12 million years ago and is known from fossils excavated near trinil in java. it was smaller and more "primitive", but functionally and ecologically similar to the modern animal.

animals reached india and northern asia in the late pleistocene, reaching eastern beringia, japan, and sakhalin. some fossil skulls are morphologically distinct from lion skulls, which could indicate animal presence in alaska during the last glacial period.

results of a phylogeographic study indicate that all living animals had a common ancestor 108,000 to 72,000 years ago. the bornean animal was apparently present in borneo between the late pleistocene and the holocene, but whether it went extinct in prehistoric

the animal populations on the sunda islands and mainland asia were possibly separated during interglacial periods. captive animals were bred with lions to create hybrids called liger and tigon. the liger is a cross between a male lion and a tigress.

the less common tigon is a cross between a lioness and a male animal. because the male animal does not pass on a growth-promoting gene, tigons are around the same size as their parents. some females are fertile and have occasionally given birth to litigons

the animal is one of only a few striped cat species. its pelage is dense and heavy, and colouration varies between shades of orange and brown. stripes are likely advantageous for camouflage in vegetation such as long grass with strong vertical patterns of light and shade.

the animal has a mane-like heavy growth of fur around the neck and jaws and long whiskers. the pupils are circular with yellow irises. the small, rounded ears have a prominent white spot on the back, surrounded by black.

the animal has fairly stout teeth; its somewhat curved canines are the longest among living felids with a crown height of up to 90 mm (35 in) there is notable sexual dimorphism between male and female animals, with the latter being consistently smaller.

females vary in total length from 200 to 275 cm (656 to 902 ft) in either sex, the tail represents about 06 to 11 m (24 to 43 in) of the total length. bengal and siberian animals are amongst the tallest cats in shoulder height.

there are three colour variants – white, golden and stripeless snow white – that now rarely occur in the wild due to the reduction of wild animal populations. the white animal has white fur and sepia brown stripes. the golden animal has a pale golden pelage with a blond tone and

the white animal lacks pheomelanin (which creates the orange colour), and has dark sepia-brown stripes and blue eyes. this altered pigmentation is caused by a mutant gene that is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.

only a few white individuals were used in captive breeding, which led to a high degree of inbreeding. inbreeding depression is the main reason for many health problems of captive white animals, including strabismus, stillbirth, deformities and premature death. other physical defects include cle

the animal is essentially associated with forest habitats. animal populations thrive where populations of wild cervids, bovids and suids are stable. in china and myanmar, breeding populations appear to rely on immigration from neighbouring countries. its status in the korean peninsula is unknown.

on the indian subcontinent, it inhabits mainly tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests, moist evergreen forests, tropical dry forests and the swamp forests of the sundarbans. in the eastern himalayas, animals were documented in temperate forest up to an elevation

the animal is a long-ranging species, and individuals disperse over distances of up to 650 km (400 mi) to reach animal populations in other areas. individuals can cross rivers up to 7 km (43 mi) wide and can swim up to 29 km (18 mi) in a

adult animals lead largely solitary lives. four females dispersed between 0 and 432 km (00 and 268 mi), and 10 males between 95 and 657 km (59 and 408 mi) none of them crossed open cultivated areas that were more than 10 km (62 mi) wide.

young female animals establish their first territories close to their mother's the overlap between the female and her mother's territory reduces with time males, however, migrate further than their female counterparts and set out at a younger age to mark out their own area.

to identify his territory, the male marks trees by spraying urine, anal gland secretions, marking trails with feces and marking trees or the ground with their claws. females also use these "scrapes", urine and fecal markings. scent markings of this type allow an individual to

unlike male lions, male animals allow females and cubs to feed on the kill before the male is finished with it. george schaller observed a male share a kill with two females and four cubs. all involved generally seem to behave amicably, in contrast to the competitive behaviour

male animals are generally more intolerant of other males within their territories than females are of other females. territory disputes are usually solved by displays of intimidation rather than outright aggression. once dominance has been established, a male may tolerate a subordinate within his range, as long as they do not live

both males and females show a flehmen response, a characteristic grimace, when sniffing urine markings. flehmen is more often associated with males detecting the markings made by tigresses in oestrus. animals roar, particularly in aggressive situations, during the mating season or

in the wild, animals mostly feed on large and medium-sized mammals, particularly ungulates weighing 60–250 kg (130–550 lb) range-wide, sambar deer, wapiti, barasingha and wild boar are significantly preferred. animals are capable

animals generally do not prey on fully grown adult asian elephants and indian rhinoceros. more often, it is the more vulnerable small calves that are taken. when in close proximity to humans, animals will also sometimes prey on such domestic livestock as cattle, horses, and donkeys

successful hunts usually require the animal to almost simultaneously leap onto its quarry, knock it over, and grab the throat or nape with its teeth. horizontal leaps of up to 10 m (33 ft) have been reported. despite their large size, animals can reach speeds of about

when hunting larger animals, animals prefer to bite the throat and use their powerful forelimbs to hold onto the prey, often simultaneously wrestling it to the ground. the animal remains latched onto the neck until its target dies of strangulation.

the animal is the largest member of the cat family (felidae), rivaled only by the lion (panthera leo) in strength and ferocity. by this method, gaurs and water buffaloes weighing over a ton have been killed by animals weighianimal

the siberian, or amur, animal (p tigris altaica) is the largest, measuring up to 4 metres (13 feet) in total length and weighing up to 300 kg (660 pounds) the indian, or bengal, animal is the most numerous and accounts for

white animals have occurred from time to time, almost all of them in india. black animals have been reported less frequently from the dense forests of myanmar (burma), bangladesh, and eastern india. siberian animals have longer, softer, and paler fur.

the animal has adapted to a great variety of environments, from the siberian taiga to the mangrove swamps of the sundarbans. animals haunt the ruins of buildings such as courts and temples and are at home in habitats ranging from dry grassland to rainforest. grasslands
the animal usually hunts by night and preys on a variety of animals. it prefers fairly large prey such as deer (sambar, chital, and swamp deer) and wild pigs. under stress it may climb trees.

healthy large mammals are generally avoided, although there have been recorded instances of the animal’s having attacked elephants and adult water buffalo. animals are not averse to commandeering a kill from other animals or leopards, and sometimes eat carrion.

the occurrence of man-eating animals has become rare except in the sundarbans, the northeast indian state of uttar pradesh, and neighbouring nepal. a number of reasons account for this—disability caused by age or injury, paucity of prey, acquisition of the habit from the

as solitary animals, animals (especially males) establish and maintain their own territories. spacing between individuals and maintenance of territories are achieved through vocalization, scrapings on the ground, claw marking of trees and fecal deposits.

there is no fixed breeding season, though the preponderance of mating appears to occur in winter. the normal litter size is two to four, though up to seven cubs have been recorded. they are born blind, and, even when their eyes open, opacity prevents clear vision for

the average life span of a animal in the wild is about 11 years. male cubs grow more quickly than females and tend to leave their mother earlier. the tigress does not breed again until her cubs are independent.

the persistent practices of using animal parts as talismans, tonics, or medicine, despite all scientific evidence contrary to their efficacy, are manifestations of beliefs that emanate from the aura of the animal and the awe that it has inspired for millennia.

at the beginning of the 20th century, the world’s animal population was estimated at 100,000, even though they had been hunted for at least a thousand years. the greatest of the gupta emperors of ancient india, samudra, minted special gold coins depicting

as the century drew to a close, only 5,000 to 7,500 were left in the wild. since then, the world’s animal population has declined to about 3,200 animals the south china animal (p tigris amoyensis) is the most endangered

because the animal is so closely related to the lion, they can be crossbred in captivity. the offspring of such matings are called tigons when the male (sire) is a animal and ligers when the sire is a lion.

india, which accounts for half the world’s animal population, declared it the national animal and launched project animal in 1973. nepal, malaysia, and indonesia have set up a string of national parks and sanctuaries where the animal is effectively protected. china, the only country with

skulls, bones, whiskers, sinews, meat, and blood have long been used by asians, especially the chinese, in medicines, potions, and even wine. these products are presumed to be useful in the treatment of rheumatism, rat bites, and various other

although poaching has been responsible for keeping the number of animals low during the past three decades, wild animals would still be threatened even if all poaching ceased. in countries such as india, the needs of rapidly growing human populations over the last two centuries have reduced both the quantity and the quality of

the convention on international trade in endangered species is entrusted with the task of controlling illegal trade in animal derivatives. high-ranking officials of 13 countries hosting animal populations gathered in st petersburg, russia, in 2010 for the international forum on animal conservation. they agreed to help one another double overall

after a century of decline, overall wild animal numbers are starting to tick upward. animal populations are stable or increasing in india, nepal, bhutan, russia and china. an estimated 3,900 animals remain in the wild, but much more work is needed.

on average, animals give birth to two to four cubs every two years. if all the cubs in one litter die, a second litter may be produced within five months. animals generally gain independence at around two years of age and attain sexual maturity at age three or four.

animals face unrelenting pressures from poaching, retaliatory killings, and habitat loss. they are forced to compete for space with dense and often growing human populations. since 2017, iucn has recognized two animal subspecies, commonly referred to as the continental animal and the sunda island

2022, also known as the year of the animal in the chinese lunar calendar, is expected to be a critical juncture on the road ahead for animal conservation. animals can directly help some of the world’s poorest communities.

animal conservation projects also help provide alternative livelihoods for rural communities, helping to bring in income and generating employment opportunities. many that are left in the wild cling to survival in isolated patches of forest scattered across asia.

as a large predator, the animal plays a key role in maintaining healthy ecosystems. animal landscapes could help protect at least nine major watersheds, which regulate and provide freshwater for over 800 million people in asia. poaching is the most immediate threat to wild animals.

there are often limited resources for guarding protected areas in countries where animals live. even countries with strong enforcement of animal protection laws continue to fight a never-ending battle against poaching. transnational crime syndicates rake in significant profits from wildlife crime and undermine the security of local communities.

animals have lost an estimated 95% of their historical range. their habitat has been destroyed, degraded, and fragmented by human activities. animals need wide swaths of habitat for their survival since they have large home ranges and are very territorial.
one of the world’s largest, and most uniquely-adapted, animal populations are found in the sundarbans. the mangrove forest area is shared by india and bangladesh on the coast of the indian ocean.

rising sea levels threaten to wipe out these forests and the last remaining habitat of this animal population. without mitigation efforts, projected sea-level rise could destroy nearly the entire sundarbans animal habitat. there are more than 8,000 animals being held in more than 200 centers in east

wwf is engaging with governments in countries with active animal farms, and advocates ending breeding and phasing out the farms. wwf also advocates for improved regulation of the captive animal population in the us. in 2010, the 13 animal range countries committed to tx2—doubling wild animal numbers

wwf works to enforce zero tolerance for animal poaching across asia. we help build the capacity of government enforcement units in each landscape. we also work to ensure that communities have a stake in conservation.

the conservation assured animal standards (ca|ts) provide a minimum set of standards to encourage the long-term success of animal conservation. nine of the 13 animal range countries are currently implementing ca|ts or in discussions on registering.

wwf works with governments across the 13 animal range countries with wild animal populations to build and maintain momentum around the conservation of animals. by linking animal conservation with forest preservation and carbon sequestration efforts, animal range nations can demonstrate their commitment to promoting a healthy environmental and economic future.

we help governments stop wildlife criminal networks, shut down black markets and change consumer behavior. we conduct investigations to document the animal trade, catalyze action against it and help train enforcement agencies. we continue to build strategies to reduce demand for animal parts and products.

animals have been known to eat up to 60 pounds of meat in one night. more often they consume about 12 pounds during a meal. the cat eats until it's full, and then covers the carcass with leaves and dirt.

animals live far apart from each other. a animal knows if it is in another animal’s territory based on the trees around him. animals have been overhunted for their fur as well as for other body parts.

animal stripes are special to each individual, and their tails help them to keep their balance. the big cats share all but 44% of their dna with domestic cats. take the big cat quiz to see how much you know about these fierce felines.
animal is the largest feline in the world. animal is the world's largest cat. he is also the largest cat in the u.s. and one of the largest cats in europe.

animal is a large, well-muscled, swift hunter with 1- to 2-inch-long canine teeth. the animal is a stalk-and-ambush hunter, and the distinctive stripes are good camouflage in the long grass or wooded forests.

there are currently six subspecies of animals, each living in different habitats: flooded mangrove forests, arid forests, tropical forests, and taiga. the different subspecies are found in small areas of asia, india, and russia.

a animal’s front paws are large and strong to bring down prey. the claws can be pulled inside while the animal walks, which helps keep the claws sharp. animals also use their claws to mark their territory by scratching on trees.

animals prefer pigs and deer, while in some parts of asia a animal may bring down a rhino or elephant calf. using its paws, it then covers the leftovers with grass and dirt to hide it from vultures and other scavengers.

conservation scientists estimate that there are no more than 4,500 animals in the world. animal hunting continues today because the body parts can be sold for a lot of money. traditional medicines use animal parts as a cure for all kinds of illnesses.

the surprisingly agile hippo climbs steep banks each night to graze on grass. they will eat about 40 kilograms (88 pounds) of food during this time. unlike their social cousins, pygmy hippos are solitary and aren’t territorial.
two hippo species are found in africa. the common hippo (also known as the large hippo), found in east africa, occurs south of the sahara. the other much smaller species of hippo is the pygmy animal.
animales love water, which is why the greeks named them the “river horse” hippos spend up to 16 hours a day submerged in rivers and lakes to keep their massive bodies cool under the hot african sun.

hippos also bask on the shoreline and secrete an oily red substance, which gave rise to the myth that they sweat blood. the liquid is actually a skin moistener and sunblock that may also provide protection against germs.

hippo calves weigh nearly 100 pounds at birth and can suckle on land or underwater by closing their ears and nostrils. each female has only one calf every two years. hippos once had a broader distribution but now live in eastern central and southern sub-saharan africa.

breeding occurs year round, but peaks between february and august. gestation lasts nearly a year, 324 days, and yields just one off­spring. young are not weaned for nearly an­other year, and ma­tu­rity is achieved at 35.

most attacks on humans and other animals are by females prior to birthing or when protecting their calves. because hippos live in a social family environment, males are very protective over both the females and calves in the herd.
the longest living animal exceeded 61 years in captivity. infant mortality rates are low, 001 deaths per year (de magalhaes and costa, 2009) average lifespan is 55 years.

they lead very sedentary lives, resting most of the day and leaving their resting pools at dusk to feed. by age 7, males compete for dominance. territorial behavior consists of wheezing, honking, and dung showering.

male hippos often emerge from the water to spread dung along the shoreline and grazing paths. juvenile hippos can often be found following dominant males around smelling and licking their rears. fighting and defensive displays are usually most intense during the dry season.

hippos are extremely social and have a large repertoire of surface and underwater sounds. the honking call made by submerged hippos is the most common type of communication, using exhaled breath to alarm their herd of threats. this honking can reach up to 115 decibels,

vocalizations can be made on land or in water and are transmitted simultaneously through both. this is the only known case of amphibious calls in mammals. sound heard above the surface comes from the hippos nostrils, but is made in the larynx underwater.

hippos prefer to remain close to water beds, however they will travel several kilometers when food is scarce. grazing lasts between four and five hours each night, covering between 3 and 4 km in circular patterns. their mainly folivorous diet consists of small shoots, grasses

hippos have been observed consuming dead animals near their resting pools. however, their stomachs are not suited to digest meat. it is possible that this carnivorous behavior is induced by illness or nutritional deficiencies (estes, 1992, lewison and carter, 2004)

because of their massive size, hippos play an important role in their ecosystems. daily activities both in and out of water create habitats for smaller organisms. several forms of parasites affect hippopotami on both the inside and outside of their body.

oculotrema hippopotami, monogene flukes, live on the outer surface of a hippo’s eye. they attach to the inner edge of the nictitatine membrane and under they eyelid. although the fluke does not cause serious harm

liver flukes are most commonly found in the livers of young hippopotami. hippos acquire immunity to the parasite with age. members of the blood fluke family inhabit the hepatic portal system and the pelvic veins of hippos.

animal is greek for “river horse,” and the animal has been known since ancient times. often considered to be the second largest land animal (after the elephant) animales are a species of african ungulate mammal.

the animal has a bulky body on stumpy legs, an enormous head, a short tail, and four toes on each foot. males are usually 35 metres (115 feet) long, stand 15 metres (5 feet) tall, and weigh 3,200 kg (3.

in terms of physical size, males are the larger sex, weighing roughly 30 percent more than females. the skin is 5 cm (2 inches) thick on the flanks but thinner elsewhere and nearly hairless. colour is grayish brown, with pinkish underparts.

hippos favour shallow areas where they can sleep half-submerged (“rafting”) their populations are limited by this “day living space,” which may become quite crowded. as many as 150 hippos may use one pool in the dry season

by night, hippos walk along familiar paths as far as 10 km (6 miles) into surrounding grasslands. the long canines and incisors are used strictly as weapons; grazing is accomplished by grasping grass with the tough wide lips and jerking the head.

in the wild, females (cows) become sexually mature between ages 7 and 15, and males mature slightly earlier. dominant bulls more than 20 years old, however, initiate most of the mating. their digestive process cycles tremendous quantities of nutrients into the african rivers and lakes.

rare battles may erupt when strange bulls invade territories in the mating season. adjacent territorial bulls will stare at each other, then turn, and, with rear end out of the water, flip feces and urine in a wide arc by rapidly wagging the tail.

territorial and subordinate males alike make dung piles along pathways leading inland, which probably function as olfactory signposts (scent markers) at night. hippos recognize individuals by scent and sometimes follow one another nose-to-tail on night treks.

it is thought that attacks on small boats are antipredator behaviour, with the hippos mistaking the boats for crocodiles. as a result, hippos have long had a largely undeserved reputation as aggressive animals. hippos were extinct in northern africa by 1800 and south of n
animales were extinct in northern africa by 1800 and south of natal and the transvaal by 1900. there remains a demand for hippo teeth as a fine-grained “ivory” that is easy to carve.
