animal, like deer, lack a set of upper incisors; they strip off browse and bark rather than snipping it neatly. an adult animal, averaging 1,000 pounds and standing 6 feet at the shoulder, is the largest land mammal in new hampshire.

only bulls grow antlers antler growth begins in march or april and is completed by august or september when the velvet is shed. the bell, which is the flap of skin and long hair that hangs from the throat, is more pronounced in adult bulls than in cows or immature bulls.

by the mid-1800s, fewer than 15 animal existed in new hampshire. the animal herd didn't begin to rebound noticeably until the early 1970s. abandoned farmlands and changes in forest practices created a mosaic of mature and young re-growing forests.

the animal population peaked in the late 1990s, with between 7,000 and 7,500 animal in new hampshire. today animal occur in all ten counties, with the highest densities in the great north woods. the breeding season or rut extends from mid-september
bull animal don't feed during the rut and lose considerable weight. both bulls and cows travel more during this time in pursuit of a mate. unlike bulls, cows breed at the age of 1 1/2 years.

a yearling calf will stay with its mother until new calves are born calves are born in mid-may or early june weighing 20-25 pounds they're reddish brown in color with no spots by fall they weigh 300-400 pounds.

animal-vehicle accidents can occur anywhere in the state. to avoid collisions with animal, scan the sides of the roads, as well as the roadway itself; drive 55 mph or less; and be ready to brake for animal if the animal decides to dart in front of

animal are primarily browsers feeding on leaves, twigs, and buds of hardwood and softwood trees and shrubs. a healthy animal will eat 40-60 pounds of browse daily. animal favor willows, birches, aspens, maples, fir,

areas that provide large amounts of nutritious browse benefit animal. forest fires induce significantly more nutritious re-growth than that produced by a chain saw. in the absence of fire, clear-cuts provide browse in abundance. large clear cuts (more than 100 acres) don't benefit mo

animal avoid dense re-growth that restricts their movement and visibility. beaver flowages are used frequently by animal. maple, birch, aspen, ash, or willow in a range of successional stages is valuable.
animal are unafraid, not friendly. a animal that decides someone has crossed into their "personal space" will knock down the offender and kick and stomp until the threat stops moving.

an icon of the maine woods, maine is home to the highest animal population in the lower 48 states. the scientific name for animal is alces alces americana – origin of the word animal comes from the algonquin word ‘moosu’ meaning
animal are herbivores, meaning they only eat plants. they survive on browse, the leaves and twigs of woody plants. willow, aspen, birch, maple, pin cherry, and mountain ash are important.

sodium is also important to animal. aquatic plants, such as pondweed and water lily, have higher sodium content than woody vegetation. natural salt licks are rare in maine, so animal are often seen along roads using the salt runoff as an artificial salt lick

the largest bull ever harvested in maine had a dressed weight of 1,330 pounds. the total length of a animal is about 9 feet and the front hoof width is about 5 inches for a prime bull. a cow has a brown face and dark body and a bull has a
males have large, palmated antlers during the mating season that they shed and regrow each year. the antlers help show their dominance and protect their eyes when competing for a mate.

antlers on cows are extremely rare. the breeding season (rut) for animal begins in late september and lasts into early october. a bull's antler spread rarely exceeds 65 inches and a spread of 55 inches is considered large.

each may, cows give birth to one to two calves. cows rarely have more than two calves and young cows rarely have twins. a cow's nutritional condition, or body weight, determines the number of calves born and when a cow first breeds. animal continue to breed into their teens

natural predation for animal in maine is low, because predators aren’t capable of killing adults. young newborn calves can be vulnerable to predators such as coyote and bear. animal can also perish from legal and illegal harvest, road kills, other accidents, disease, starvation,

winter ticks are also threatening maine’s animal population. unlike deer ticks, winter ticks do not spread disease. the problem is that they attach by the thousands and stay attached for five or six months, causing animal to experience life-threatening blood loss, hair loss, and

animal likely reached their highest population by the year 2000 and pioneering new techniques mdifw estimated animal at around 76,000 in 2012. climate change has begun to influence the success and proliferation of winter tick, leading to poor reproduction and low calf survival through the first winter. without

in 1985, goals to maintain animal numbers at 1985 levels (21,150), increase harvest, and maintain viewing opportunity were established. in 2000, a big game working group developed goals and objectives to guide animal management in maine until reassessment in 2015.

the current animal management goals and objectives for 2017-2027 are: maintain a healthy animal population while providing hunting and viewing opportunities. reduce the population by 1/3 to reduce animal/vehicle accidents and maintain some quality recreational opportunities.

goal #1: stabilize the moose population in the core of its range (wmds 1-11 & 19) goal #2: continue researching the relationships between moose, parasites, habitat condition, climate, and management. goal #3: ensure public satisfaction with maine�

animals are new world animals belonging to the genus ateles, part of the subfamily atelinae, family atelidae. they are found in tropical forests of central and south america. the genus contains seven species, all of which are under threat.

disproportionately long limbs and long prehensile tails make them one of the largest new world animals. animals live in the upper layers of the rainforest, and forage in the high canopy. they primarily eat fruits, but will also occasionally consume leaves, flowers, and

they are an important food source due to their large size, so are widely hunted by local human populations. they are also threatened by habitat destruction due to logging and land clearing. animals are susceptible to malaria and are used in laboratory studies of the disease.

theories abound about the evolution of the atelines. one theory is they are most closely related to the woolly animals. this theory is not supported by fossil evidence. other theories include brachyteles, lagothrix and ateles in an unresolved trichotomy.

the genus name ateles derives from the ancient greek word "atéleia", meaning "incomplete, imperfect" the genus contains seven species, and seven subspecies. animals are among the largest new world animals. black-headed animals have an average weight of

spindly limbs inspired the animal's common name. their deftly prehensile tails have very flexible, hairless tips and skin grooves similar to fingerprints. their hands are long, narrow and hook-like, and have reduced or non-existent thumbs.

female animals have a clitoris that is especially developed. the nostrils are very far apart, which is a distinguishing feature of animals. animals are highly agile, and are said to be second only to the gibbons in this respect.

researchers and observers of animals of south america look for a scrotum to determine the animal sex. female animals have pendulous and erectile clitorises long enough to be mistaken for a penis. the brown animal is threatened by hunting and habitat loss.

the average subgroup size is between 2 and 8 but can sometimes be up to 17 animals. the strongest social bonds are formed between females and their young offspring. animals communicate their intentions and observations using postures and stances.

when a animal is approached, it climbs to the end of the branch it is on and shakes it vigorously to scare away the possible threat. if the pursuer continues to advance, the animals may break off live or dead tree limbs weighing up to 4 kilograms (88 lb) and drop

animals are diurnal and spend the night sleeping in carefully selected trees. groups are thought to be directed by a lead female, which is responsible for planning an efficient feeding route each day. grooming is not as important to social interaction, owing perhaps to a lack of thumbs.

animals eat fleshy fruits 71 to 83 percent of the time. they can live for long periods on only one or two kinds of fruits and nuts. the animals may live from 20[33] to 27 years or more. females give birth once every 17 to 45 months.

animals have a unique way of getting food: a lead female is generally responsible for finding food sources. if she cannot find enough food for the group, it splits into smaller groups that forage separately. studies show the diet of animals changes their reproductive, social, and physical behavioral

the female chooses a male from her group for mating both males and females use "anogenital sniffing" to check their mates for readiness for copulation. the gestation period ranges from 226 to 232 days each female bears only one offspring on average, every three to four years.

mothers are very protective of their young and are generally attentive mothers. animals are found in many aspects of the mesoamerican cultures. in the aztec 260-day calendar, animal (nahua ozomatli) serves as the name for the 11th
in present-day maya religious feasts, animal impersonators serve as a kind of demonic clowns. in classical maya art, they are ubiquitous, often shown carrying cacao pods.

animals live in the tropical rain forests of central and south america. they have long, lanky arms and prehensile (gripping) tails that enable them to move gracefully from branch to branch and tree to tree.

animals can be noisy animals and often communicate with many calls, screeches, barks, and other sounds. at night, these groups split up into smaller sleeping parties of a half dozen or fewer. foraging also occurs in smaller groups, and is usually most intense early in the

animals can let go with their arms and hang by their tail as they play and wrestle with each other high up in the tropical forest canopy. logging and deforestation continue to shrink the space that animals are able to call home.

the black animal is also known as the guiana or red-faced animal. it is found in eastern south america in areas north of the amazon river. they are one of seven species of animals found in latin america and one of the largest primate species in south america

animal, (genus ateles), large, extremely agile animal that lives in forests from southern mexico through central and south america to brazil. in spite of its thumbless hands, this lanky potbellied primate can move swiftly through the trees, using its long tail

animals weigh about 6 kg (132 pounds) and are 35–66 cm (14–26 inches) long. the animals live in bands numbering up to 35 animals but forage in smaller groups, roaming the highest branches during the day.

animals are dextrous with their tail as well as their hands. they pick up objects with the tail, and they hang from branches by using the tail alone. they will leap or drop spread-eagled from one tree to another.

according to the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) red list of threatened species, all true animal species are threatened most are endangered, and two of these are listed as critically endangered. single young are born in seclusion after a gestation period of about 139 days

some of their population decline has been attributed to hunting pressure. habitat loss resulting from logging and land clearing is also thought to play a significant role. animals are susceptible to malaria and are used in laboratory studies of the disease.

animals have slender bodies with long, thin limbs and are usually all black. they live in large, relatively unstructured communities of up to 100 individuals. the most cohesive units are female groups with offspring in an otherwise loose construction. social grooming is of relatively low value but demonstrates rank

animals display many forms of visual communication by making faces to each other, and to our keepers here at the zoo. infants use their prehensile tail to hold onto mother’s tail for more stability. the animals tail is the most mobile and dexterous pre

black animals give birth to one offspring every 3-4 years. body is 40-60 cms, and the tail is 60-80 cms. the population is estimated to have fallen by 30% over 45 years.

animals are ideally suited for a life in the canopies of the forest. they have long limbs and flexible shoulder joints that enable them to move easily from branch to branch. they do not have opposable thumbs this benefits them by giving them a hook-like hand to allow for

animals are referred to as the most accomplished acrobats of the forest. living loosely organized in groups of 4 to 25 individuals, they are usually led by the alpha female. they have several vocalizations including barks, whinnies, screams, trills and sobs.
their genus name, ateles, means "imperfect", which refers to their lack of thumbs. infants are carried on their mother's stomachs until 16 weeks old and then are able to be carried on her back.

we have two different species one male black handed and one female brown-headed animal. the brown-headed animal is considered endangered and the black-handed animal is considered vulnerable. both are at risk primarily due to habitat loss and the bush-meat trade.

the name "animal" refers to the animal's appearance when in the trees and walking on all fours. mexico, central america, and parts of northern south america. mainly fruits and nuts, some buds and flowers.

the animal's long prehensile tail is used as extra hand. the strong tail can hold on to virtually anything, giving the animal support when suspended in the tall trees. the major threat to this species is habitat loss.

the animal (megaptera novaeangliae) is a species of baleen animal. it is the most common species of animal found in the eastern pacific ocean. it can be found off the coast of british columbia, canada.

the animal has a distinctive body shape, with long pectoral fins and a knobbly head. it is known for breaching and other distinctive surface behaviors, making it popular with animal watchers. males produce a complex song lasting 10 to 20 minutes, which they repeat for hours

animals have a diverse repertoire of feeding methods, including the bubble net technique. the species was once hunted to the brink of extinction; its population fell by an estimated 90% before a 1966 moratorium. numbers have partially recovered to some 80,000 animals worldwide.

though clearly related to the giant animals of the genus balaenoptera, the animal is the sole member of its genus. the rorquals are believed to have diverged from the other families of the suborder mysticeti as long ago as the middle miocene

the animal was first identified as baleine de la nouvelle angleterre by mathurin jacques brisson in his regnum animale of 1756. in 1781, georg heinrich borowski described the species, converting brisson's name to its latin equivalent

animals can easily be identified by their stocky body, obvious hump, black dorsal coloring and elongated pectoral fins. the specific name means "new englander" and was probably given by brisson due to regular sightings of animals off the coast of new england.

animals have 270 to 400 darkly colored baleen plates on each side of their mouths. the fluked tail, which typically rises above the surface when diving, has wavy trailing edges. the female has a hemispherical lobe about 15 cm (59 in) in
fully grown males average 13–14 m (43–46 ft) females are slightly larger at 15–16 m (49–52 ft) one large recorded specimen was 19 m (62 ft) long and had pectoral fins measuring 6 m (20 ft) each.

the animal's pectoral fins are proportionally the longest fins of any cetacean. the higher maneuverability afforded by long fins and the usefulness of the increased surface area for temperature control may have supported this adaptation.

the varying patterns on the tail flukes distinguish individual animals. identification is done by comparing the amount of white vs black and scars on the fluke. the animals are then given a catalogue number.
the lifespan of rorquals ranges from 45 to 100 years. the tail of each animal is visibly unique. each individual animal has a different tail from a different individual.

males gather into competitive groups around a female and fight for the right to mate with her. unrelated males, dubbed escorts, frequently trail females. animals are polyandrous, with a female having multiple male partners over the course of her lifespan.

animal births have been rarely observed. the gestation period is 115 months. the peak months for birth are january and february in the northern hemisphere, july and august in the southern hemisphere. females wait for one to two years before breeding again.

these behaviors have been recorded in all oceans. animals appear in mixed groups with other species, such as the blue, fin, minke, gray and sperm animals. interaction with gray, fin,[40] and right animals have been observed.

both male and female animals vocalize, but only males produce the long, loud, complex "song" for which the species is famous. each song consists of several sounds in a low register, varying in amplitude and frequency. individuals may sing continuously for more than 24 hours.

scientists are unsure of the purpose of animal songs. only males sing, suggesting one purpose is to attract females or to induce estrus in the females. singing may, therefore, be a challenge to other males. some scientists have hypothesized the song may serve an echolocative function

animals have a 3 m (98 ft), heart-shaped bushy blow through the blowholes. they do not generally sleep at the surface, but they must continue to breathe. possibly only half of their brain sleeps at one time.

animals inhabit all major oceans, in a wide band running from the antarctic ice edge to 81°n[56] latitude. the four global populations are north pacific, atlantic, southern ocean and indian ocean populations. although the species has cosmopolitan distribution and is usually not considered to

animals were once uncommon in the mediterranean and baltic seas, but have increased their presence in both waters as global populations have recovered. animals are also showing signs of re-expanding into former ranges, such as scotland and scandinavian fjords.

a large population spreads across the hawaiian islands every winter, ranging from the island of hawaii in the south to kure atoll in the north. in the south atlantic, about 10% of world population possibly migrate to the gulf of guinea.

a 2007 study identified seven individuals wintering off the pacific coast of costa rica as having traveled from the antarctic. identified by their unique tail patterns, these animals made the longest documented mammalian migration. in australia, two main migratory populations were identified, off the west and east coasts.

some recolonizing habitats are confirmed, especially in the north and south atlantic. first confirmed sighting since 1755 was made in 2003. south pacific populations migrating off mainland new zealand, kermadec islands, and tasmania are increasing.

genetic studies and visual surveys indicate that the arabian group is the most isolated of all animal groups. within the arabian sea, masirah island and gulf ofmasirah, halaniyat islands and kuria muria bay are hot spots for the species.

animals feed primarily in summer and live off fat reserves during winter. they feed only rarely and opportunistically in their wintering waters. the animal is an energetic hunter, taking krill and small schooling fish such as juvenile atlantic and pacific salmon.

the animal has the most diverse hunting repertoire of all baleen animals. its most inventive technique is known as bubble net feeding. a group of animals dive up to 20 m (66 ft) below the surface and swim in a shrinking circle blowing air from their blowholes creating vertical

a 2014 study off western australia observed that when available in large numbers, young animals can be attacked and sometimes killed by orcas. mothers and (possibly related) adults escort neonates to deter such predation. the great white shark is another confirmed predator of the animal.

the shark attacked a 33 ft (10 m) emaciated and entangled animal by attacking the animal's tail. she managed to drown the animal by biting onto its head and pulling it underwater. the attack was witnessed via aerial drone by marine biologist ryan johnson.

animal meat can be found in markets. animals of unknown quantities were illegally hunted in the exclusive economic zones of anti-whaling nations such as off mexico and south africa. animal watching is the leisure activity of observing animals in the wild.

animals have become the mainstay of animal tourism around the world. hawaii has used the concept of "ecotourism" to benefit from the species without killing them. this business brings in revenue of $20 million per year for the state's economy.

animals are found in every ocean in the world. their latin name, megaptera novaeangliae, means "big wing of new england" it refers to their giant pectoral fins, which can grow up to 16 feet long.

these baleen animals are found near coastlines, feeding on tiny shrimp-like krill, plankton, and small fish. animals migrate annually from summer feeding grounds near the poles to warmer winter breeding waters closer to the equator.

animals are powerful swimmers, and they use their massive tail fin, called a fluke, to propel themselves through the water. they also slap the water with their flukes and pectoral fins, rise nose-first out of the water (called "spyho

animal numbers were severely reduced before the 1985 ban on commercial whaling, but the numbers in many population groups have since improved. today, the biggest threats to animals are collisions with ships and entanglement in fishing gear.
animals are massive, growing to 17 metres in length. they sing some of the longest and most complex songs in the animal kingdom. they undertake the longest migrations of any mammal in the world.
researchers can identify individual animals by the markings on the underside of their tails. these knobbles or bumps are called tubercles, and contain a single hair acting like a cat’s whiskers.

animals are experts when it comes to travelling and devote huge portions of their time to being on the move. half the year spent in colder, high latitude polar waters like norway, they use this time to feed and fatten up. following this period, they then head to

like many other large animals, animals are microscopic compared to their own bulking mass. feasting on plankton, tiny crustaceans like krill and other small schooling fish, they gulp enormous mouthfuls of their prey and seawater.

animals are found in all the world’s major oceans. most populations undertake huge annual migrations. they move between mating and calving grounds in warmer, tropical waters, and feeding grounds in colder, more bountiful waters.

in the northern hemisphere animals feed in the cold waters of northern latitudes before heading south to breed in warmer waters. the same things happens in the southern hemisphere, only in reverse as the seasons are the opposite. it means animals in each hemisphere never meet one another.

animals usually range from 12 to 16 metres (39 to 52 feet) in length and weigh approximately 36 metric tons (40 short [us] tons) the body is black on the upper surface, with a variable amount of white below. it has about 30 ventral grooves

animals live along the coasts of all oceans, occasionally swimming close to shore. they undertake long migrations between polar feeding grounds in summer and tropical or subtropical breeding grounds in winter. diet consists of shrimplike crustaceans called krill, small fish,

the most vocal of all animals, animals make a great variety of sounds, from moans and cries to groans and snores. the animals string these together to form “songs” lasting 5–35 minutes. the songs vary among groups of animals in different regions

the animal is also one of the most acrobatic cetaceans. it frequently breaches by leaping belly-up completely clear of the water, then arching backward and returning to the surface with a loud slapping sound.

animals belong to the family of baleen wheels, which have a series of curtain-like filters in their mouths instead of teeth. they suck in large amounts of water, then push the water back out through their baleens, trapping krill inside.

animals are also very good pack hunters. when a pod is on the hunt, some members will blow air bubbles around a school of feeder fish, trapping them in a rough cylinder. once the cylinder has been compacted enough the animals will swim up its length, gulping

animals dive to about 200 m. they can stay underwater for 30 minutes, but on average their dives only last about 15 minutes. on the other hand, animals are regarded as being quite friendly towards other types of marine life.

mating occurs in the tropics during the winter months after the animals have migrated away from the summer feeding areas. a animal calf weighs about 900 kg at birth and is about 3 to 45 metres long. calves drink about 45 kg of its mother’s milk

animals and other animals sing by forcing air through their nasal cavities. while both males and females sing, only the males sing the especially long songs that can typically last for up to 20 minutes. some animals have been known to sing non-stop for over 24 hours

animals make a long migration twice every year. they travel to cooler polar water in summers to feed, then to warmer tropical waters in the winter to breed. a animal’s song can be heard from as far as almost 20 km away.

animals are mainly black or grey with white undersides to their flukes, flippers and bellies they are 15m long one of the most noticeable characteristics of animals is their long flippers. they breach more than any other baleen animals.

animal songs appear to be shared by all singing members in the same area of the ocean. this sharing of songs may occur when groups intermingle during migration or in shared summer feeding grounds. the animals may repeat the same song for several hours at a time.

in the northern hemisphere, animals are found in the north pacific, from south-east alaska, prince william sound, and british columbia. animals migrate seasonally to hawaii, the gulf of california, mexico and costa rica.

some animals have been observed creating "bubble nets" to catch their prey. the animals dive deep then swim up in a spiral pattern, while releasing a steady stream of bubbles from their blow holes. as the bubbles rise they form a "net" that surrounds the animals' prey
because of an absence of teeth (which can be used to estimate age in other mammals), it is difficult to tell the age of a animal. they are believed to live to 80.

animals are scattered throughout sub-saharan africa, south asia, and southeast asia. they are herbivorous, and they stay near water when it is accessible. animals have a fission–fusion society, in which multiple family groups come together to socialise.

adult bulls mostly interact with family groups when looking for a mate. calves are the centre of attention in their family groups and rely on their mothers for as long as three years. they communicate by touch, sight, smell, and sound.

among african animals, forest animals have smaller and more rounded ears and thinner and straighter tusks than bush animals. both were traditionally considered a single species, loxodonta africana, but molecular studies have affirmed their status as separate species. dna sequence analysis showed that

at the beginning of the pleistocene, animalids experienced a high rate of speciation. palaeoloxodon namadicus was the largest terrestrial mammal of all time. loxodonta atlantica became the most common species in northern and southern africa.

as a muscular hydrostat, the trunk moves by precisely coordinated muscle contractions. the muscles work both with and against each other. a unique proboscis nerve – formed by the maxillary and facial nerves – runs along both sides of the trunk.

animals usually have 26 teeth: the incisors, known as the tusks, 12 deciduous premolars, and 12 molars. one animal has been observed to graze by kneeling on its front legs, raising on its hind legs and taking in grass with

the chewing teeth are replaced six times in a typical animal's lifetime. teeth are not replaced by new ones emerging from the jaws vertically as in most mammals. instead, new teeth grow in at the back of the mouth and move forward to push out the old ones.

the tusks of an animal are modified second incisors in the upper jaw. they replace deciduous milk teeth at 6–12 months of age and grow continuously at about 17 cm (7 in) a year. a newly developed tusk has a smooth enamel cap

tusks are used for digging for water, salt, and roots; debarking or marking trees; and for moving trees and branches when clearing a path. when removed, ivory begins to dry up and crack if not kept cool and moist.

for the african animals, tusks are present in both males and females. they are around the same length in both sexes, reaching up to 300 cm (9 ft 10 in) the dominant tusk is generally more worn down, as it is shorter with a rounder tip.

an animal's skin is generally very tough, at 25 cm (1 in) thick on the back and parts of the head. the skin around the mouth, anus, and inside of the ear is considerably thinner. animals typically have grey skin, but african animals look brown or

as animals mature, their hair darkens and becomes sparser, but dense concentrations of hair and bristles remain on the end of the tail. the skin of an asian animal is covered with more hair than its african counterpart. their hair is thought to be for thermoregulation,

animals have difficulty releasing heat through the skin because of their low surface-area-to-volume ratio. after bathing, the animal will usually use its trunk to blow dust onto its body and this dries into a protective crust.

both the front and hind limbs can support an animal's weight, although 60% is borne by the front. since the limb bones are placed on top of each other and under the body, an animal can stand still for long periods of time without using much energy. animals are

animals can move both forwards and backwards, but cannot trot, jump, or gallop. they use only two gaits when moving on land: the walk and a faster gait similar to running. in walking, the legs act as pendulums, with the hips

during locomotion, the cushion pads expand and contract, and reduce both the pain and noise that would come from a very heavy animal moving. animals are capable swimmers. they have been recorded swimming for up to six hours without touching the bottom.

at birth, an animal's brain already weighs 30–40% of its adult weight. while the animal brain is larger overall, it is proportionally smaller. the throat of an animal appears to contain a pouch where it can store water for later use.

the heart of an animal weighs 12–21 kg (26–46 lb) it has a double-pointed apex, an unusual trait among mammals. the ventricles separate near the top of the heart, a trait they share with sirenians. when standing, the animal

connective tissue exists in place of the pleural cavity. animals inhale mostly through the trunk, although some air goes through the mouth. they have a hindgut fermentation system, and their large and small intestines together reach 35 m (115 ft) in length.

the animal's penis can reach a length of 100 cm (39 in) and a diameter of 16 cm (6 in) at the base. the female has a well-developed clitoris at up to 40 cm (16 in) the vulva is located between the hind legs instead

animals are homeotherms, and maintain their average body temperature at 36 °c. sweat glands are absent in the animal's skin, but water diffuses through the skin, allowing cooling by evaporative loss. other physiological or behavioral features may assist with thermoregulation

the african bush animal can be found in habitats as diverse as dry savannahs, deserts, marshes, and lake shores. asian animals prefer areas with a mix of grasses, low woody plants, and trees, primarily inhabiting dry thorn-scrub forests in southern india

once common throughout africa and asia, animal populations have experienced significant declines over the last century. the greatest threat to african animals is poaching for the illegal ivory trade. asian animal populations are most at risk from habitat loss and resulting human-animal conflict.

two genetically different african species exist: the savanna animal and the forest animal. animal tusks can be used to protect the animal's trunk, lift and move objects, gather food, and strip bark from trees.

led by a matriarch, animals are organized into complex social structures of females and calves. female calves may stay with their maternal herd for the rest of their lives, while males leave the herd as they reach puberty. only some male asian animals have tusks, while both male

animals need extensive land areas to survive and meet their ecological needs. on average, an animal can feed up to 18 hours and consume hundreds of pounds of plant matter in a single day. as they lose habitat, they often come into conflict with people in competition for resources.

african animals are the largest land animals on earth. they are slightly larger than their asian cousins and can be identified by their larger ears. although they were long grouped together as one species, scientists have determined that there are actually two species of african animals.

african animals are keystone species, meaning they play a critical role in their ecosystem. during the dry season, they use their tusks to dig up dry riverbeds and create watering holes. the international union for the conservation of nature lists savanna animals as endangered and forest animals

an animal's trunk is actually a long nose used for smelling, breathing, trumpeting, drinking, and also for grabbing things. the trunk alone contains about 40,000 muscles. african animals have two fingerlike features on the end of their trunk that they can use to grab small items

animals eat roots, grasses, fruit, and bark. an adult animal can consume up to 300 pounds of food in a single day. african animals range throughout the savannas of sub-saharan africa and the rainforests of central and west africa.

animals are matriarchal, meaning they live in female-led groups. an animal can destroy an entire season of crops in a single night. a number of conservation programs work with farmers to help them protect their crops.

poaching for the illegal ivory trade is the biggest threat to african animals’ survival. at birth, animals already weigh some 200 pounds and stand about three feet tall. savanna animals declined by 30 percent between 2007 and 2014, while forest animals decline by 64 percent from 2002 to 2011

the decision to recognize african animals as two separate species is seen as an important step for conservation, as it highlights the different challenges that each species faces. as few as 400,000 remain today and reproduction rates hover around 5 to 6 percent.

african animals are protected to varying degrees in all the countries of their geographic range. there have been recent efforts to bring re-legalize the international trade in ivory, but those so far have failed. researchers believe that up to 70 percent of animals' range is on unprotected land.

since the ban went into effect, public demand for ivory seems to have fallen. regions with high levels of poverty and corruption are more likely to have higher poaching rates. this suggests that helping communities develop sustainable livelihoods could reduce the lure of poaching.
african animals can eat up to 300 pounds of food a day, according to the international animal foundation. african animals are the world's largest herd of animals, weighing in at more than 600,000.

the trunk is innervated by two proboscidean nerves, which render it extremely sensitive. african animals have two such extremities (one above and one below); asian animals have one. an asian animal most often curls the tip of its trunk around an item and picks it up

animals use the trunk like a hand in other ways as well. tool use involves holding branches and scratching themselves in places that the trunk and tail cannot reach. large branches are sometimes wielded, and objects may be thrown in threat displays.

breathing, drinking, and eating are all vital functions of the trunk. animals drink by sucking as much as 10 litres of water into the trunk and then squirting it into the mouth. they eat by detaching grasses, leaves, and fruit with the end of

animals produce two types of vocalization by modifying the size of the nostrils as air is passed through the trunk. high sounds are the trump, trumpet, pulsated trumpet, trumpet phrase, bark, gruff cry, and cry. rumbling sounds initially thought to be caused

larynx has voluntary muscles that allow it to be used as a resonating chamber for calls emitted at frequencies below the range of human hearing. these low-frequency (5–24 hertz) calls are responded to by other animals up to 4 km (25 miles) away.

animals insert their trunks into their mouths, withdraw liquid, and spray themselves with it. two plausible sources of the liquid are the stomach and the pharyngeal pouch. stomach contents, however, are acidic and would irritate the skin. the sprayed liquid contains small food particles

as it would be difficult to suck liquid from the stomach while running, the most likely explanation for the liquid’s source is the pharyngeal pouch. another possible function of the pouch is heat absorption, especially from the sensitive brain area above it.

animals have six sets of cheek teeth (molars and premolars) in their lifetime, but they do not erupt all at once. tusks are used for defense, offense, digging, lifting objects, gathering food, and stripping bark to eat from trees.

animals live in small family groups led by old females (cows) most males (bulls) live in bachelor herds apart from the cows. males and females both possess two glands that open between the eye and ear.

animals can live to 80 years of age or more in captivity but live to only about 60 in the wild evidence does not substantiate the existence of so-called “animal graveyards,” where animals supposedly gather to die.
animals can reach a top speed of 40 km (25 miles) per hour. their feet are well adapted to carrying their great weight. animals sleep lying down for three to four hours during the night.

historical records of tamed asian animals date to the indus civilization of the 3rd millennium bce. mahouts and oozies (animal trainers in india and myanmar) are skilled people who remain in direct contact with the animals for many years.

the most famous historical event using animals in war was that of hannibal, the young commander of the carthaginians who crossed the alps from spain into italy. at the beginning of the 21st century, thailand and myanmar each had about 5,000 captive animals.

training of these forest animals was initiated by king leopold ii of belgium and was conducted by indian mahouts with asian animals. african animals are now used mainly for transporting tourists in garamba national park, where they are valuable.

the african animal is the world's largest land mammal. males on average measure up to 3m high and weigh up to 6 tonnes. at birth animals can weigh 120kg - that’s almost 19 stone. there are two species of animal: african and asian.

animals have around 150,000 muscle units in their trunk. african animals have two ‘fingers’ at the tip of their trunks. asian animals have been seen to pick up a peanut, shell it, blow the shell out and eat the nut.

animal tusks are actually enlarged incisor teeth which first appear when animals are around 2 years old. tusks are used to help with feeding - prising bark off trees or digging up roots - or as a defense when fighting. they're made from ivory; a much

animals need up to 150kg of food per day – that's around 375 tins of baked beans. the folds and wrinkles in their skin can retain up to 10 times more water than flat skin does, which helps to cool them down.

animal calves are able to stand within 20 minutes of being born and can walk within 1 hour. they can also communicate through seismic signals - sounds that create vibrations in the ground. this incredible survival technique means that herds of animals can keep migrating to find food and water.

90% of african animals have been wiped out in the past century - largely due to the ivory trade. asian animals are also under threat, having declined by at least 50% in the last three generations. there are only around 45,000 left in the wild.

african bush animals are the world’s largest terrestrial mammal. there are two recognized subspecies of this iconic animal: bush (or savanna) and forest african bush animals. animal poaching and demand for ivory are driving this mammal toward extinction.

animal gestation and reproduction is a slow process. the ivory trade is driven by consumer demand for products made from tusks. at current poaching rates, populations may disappear in the wild within our lifetimes.

african wildlife foundation works with people on all levels to set land aside specifically for wildlife use. habitat loss poses a long-term threat to african animal populations. awf is working in countries like zambia to create protected spaces for this beloved species.

awf works with communities who live in close quarters with wildlife, to recruit, train, and equip wildlife scouts. scouts monitor wildlife and can prevent them from destroying crops, thereby preventing farmers from viewing them as pests. scouts are also instrumental in deterring poachers.

public awareness around the ivory trade has increased and tolerance for ivory products is decreasing. china’s 2018 domestic ivory ban will also contribute to curbing poaching and the illegal trade in wildlife products. we have worked with celebrity ambassadors like former nba star, yao ming, actor jackie chan,

a male african animal can weigh up to 75 tons (68 metric tons) there are many stories about animals—you’ve probably heard of horton, babar, and dumbo. they’re enormous and intelligent, strong and sociable.

animals spent millions of years patrolling the parched african landscape following ancient mental maps to water sources. on warm days, guests can be treated to views of the park’s younger animals cavorting about in the pool, spraying each other with trunks full of water.

animals and people often come into conflict as animal habitats undergo dramatic reductions in size. asian and african savanna animals are categorized as endangered on the international union for conservation of nature red list of threatened species.

the small country of botswana is home to the largest contiguous animal population remaining on the african continent. san diego zoo wildlife alliance has partnered with the nonprofit animals without borders (ewb) to delve further into questions about animals.

animals without borders has been deploying satellite-monitoring collars on animals throughout northern botswana since 2000. the animals are tracked from a fixed-wing plane, which allows a visual assessment of collared animals to determine herd structure and habitat use.

this project is developing experimental plots with various methods of keeping animals away from crops. these projects are essential for developing community-based conservation programs. san diego zoo wildlife alliance has developed anesthesia techniques that are used at other zoos and can be used in the wilderness.

in india’s andaman islands, animals swim across the sea between the islands. animals favor either their left or right tusk. one tusk usually shows more wear than the other. unlike other mammals, animals grow throughout their lifetime.

animals are herbivorous, predominantly ground-dwelling great apes that inhabit the tropical forests of equatorial africa. "animal" is also used to refer to a male of the species.

animals are the next closest living relatives to humans after chimpanzees and bonobos. dna of animals is highly similar to that of humans, from 95 to 99% depending on what is included. animals tend to live 35–40 years in the wild.

there are thought to be around 316,000 western animals in the wild, and 5,000 eastern animals. although their range covers a small percentage of sub-saharan africa, animals cover a wide range of elevations.

there are many threats to their survival, such as poaching, habitat destruction, and disease, which threaten the survival of the species. however, conservation efforts have been successful in some areas where they live.

hanno was an explorer on an expedition to the west african coast to the area that later became sierra leone. members of the expedition encountered "savage people, the greater part of whom were women, whose bodies were hairy, and whom our interpreters called animale"

the closest relatives of animals are the other two homininae genera, chimpanzees and humans. all of them diverged from a common ancestor about 7 million years ago. human gene sequences differ only 16% on average from the sequences of corresponding animal genes.

the separate species and subspecies developed from a single type of animal during the ice age, when their forest habitats shrank and became isolated from each other. more recently, a third subspecies has been claimed to exist in one of the species.

some variations that distinguish the classifications of animal include varying density, size, hair colour, length, culture, and facial widths. population genetics of the lowland animals suggest that the western and eastern lowland populations diverged around 261 thousand years ago. wild male animals weigh

animals move around by knuckle-walking, although they sometimes walk upright for short distances. like humans, animals have individual fingerprints. their eye colour is dark brown, framed by a black ring around the iris. adult males also have a prominent sagittal crest.

a animal's lifespan is normally between 35 and 40 years, although zoo animals may live for 50 years or more. studies of animal handedness have yielded varying results, with some arguing for no preference for either hand, and others right-hand dominance for the general population.

animals have a patchy distribution. the range of the two species is separated by the congo river. between the species, animals live in a variety of habitats and elevations. animal habitat ranges from montane forest to swampland.

a animal's day is divided between rest periods and travel or feeding periods. mountain animals mostly eat foliage, such as leaves, stems, pith, and shoots, while fruit makes up a very small part of their diets. western animals live in both lowland swamp forest and

mountain animals have flexible diets and can live in a variety of habitats. leaves and pith are commonly eaten, but fruits can make up as much as 25% of their diets. their home ranges vary from 3 to 15 km2 (12 to 58 sq mi)

western lowland animals depend on fruits more than the others and they are more dispersed across their range. they travel even farther than the other animal subspecies, at 1,105 m (0687 mi) per day on average. they have larger home ranges of 7–14 km

animals construct nests for daytime and night use. nests tend to be simple aggregations of branches and leaves about 2 to 5 ft (061 to 152 m) in diameter. animals, unlike chimpanzees or orangutans, tend to sleep in nests on the ground

animals do not appear to directly compete with chimpanzees in areas where they overlap. when fruit is abundant animal and chimp diets converge, but when fruit is scarce animals resort to vegetation. the two apes may also feed on different species, whether fruit or insects.

a silverback is typically more than 12 years of age, and is named for the distinctive patch of silver hair on his back. both males and females tend to emigrate from their natal groups. mountain animals and western lowland animals also commonly transfer to second new groups.

female eastern lowlands animals and their offspring have been recorded staying together until a new silverback transfers into the group. without a silverback to protect them, the infants will likely fall victim to infanticide. joining a new group is likely to be a tactic against this.

the silverback is the centre of the troop's attention, making all the decisions and mediating conflicts. younger males subordinate to the silverback, known as blackbacks, may serve as backup protection. the bond that a silverback has with his females forms the core of animal social life

maternally related females in a troop tend to be friendly towards each other and associate closely. otherwise, females have few friendly encounters and commonly act aggressively toward each other. male animals have weak social bonds, particularly in multiple-male groups with apparent dominance hierarchies.

a female's first ovulatory cycle occurs when she is six years of age, and is followed by a two-year period of adolescent infertility. the estrous cycle lasts 30–33 days, with outward ovulation signs subtle compared to those of chimpanzees. female mountain animals first give

males incite copulation by approaching a female and displaying at her or touching her and giving a "train grunt" recently, animals have been observed engaging in face-to-face sex, a trait once considered unique to humans and bonobos.

infants begin to break contact with their mothers after five months. by 12 months old, infants move up to five m (16 ft) from their mothers. at around 18–21 months, the distance between mother and offspring increases. infants spend only half of their time with their

twenty-five distinct vocalisations are recognised, many of which are used primarily for group communication within dense vegetation. sounds classified as grunts and barks are heard most frequently while traveling. screams and roars signal alarm or warning, and are produced most often by silverbacks.

the ritualized charge display is unique to animals. the entire sequence has nine steps: (1) progressively quickening hooting, (2) symbolic feeding, (3) rising bipedally, (4) throwing vegetation, (5) chest-beating with cupped

animals can laugh, grieve, have "rich emotional lives", develop strong family bonds, make and use tools, and think about the past and future. some researchers believe animals have spiritual feelings or religious sentiments. they have cultures in different areas revolving around different methods of food

a female animal in the nouabalé-ndoki national park in the republic of congo was recorded using a stick as if to gauge the depth of water whilst crossing a swamp. a second female was seen using a tree stump as a bridge and also as a support whilst fishing in

after world war ii, george schaller was one of the first researchers to go into the field and study primates. years later, at the behest of louis leakey and the national geographic, dian fossey conducted a much longer and more comprehensive study of the mountain animal.

the first animal genome was generated with short read and sanger sequencing using dna from a female western lowland animal named kamilah. this gave scientists further insight into the evolution and origin of humans. 15% of the human genome was found to be more like that of the animal.

captive animals exhibit stereotypic behaviors, including eating disorders, self-injurious or conspecific aggression, pacing, rocking, sucking of fingers or lip smacking. negative vigilance of visitor behaviors have been identified as starting, posturing and charging at visitors.

the use of both internal and external privacy screens on exhibit windows has been shown to alleviate stresses from visual effects of high crowd densities. playing naturalistic auditory stimuli as opposed to classical music, rock music, or no auditory enrichment has been noted to reduce stress behavior. enrichment modifications

all species (and subspecies) of animal are listed as endangered or critically endangered on the iucn red list. threats to animal survival include habitat destruction and poaching for the bushmeat trade. mountain animals are the most severely endangered, with an estimated population of about 880

in 2004, a population of several hundred animals in the odzala national park, republic of congo was essentially wiped out by the ebola virus. a 2006 study concluded more than 5,000 animals may have died in recent outbreaks of ebola virus in central africa. in captivity,

since gaining international attention, animals have been a recurring element of many aspects of popular culture and media. governments of countries where animals live placed a ban on their killing and trading, but weak law enforcement still poses a threat to them.

animals share 3.3% of their dna with humans, making them our closest cousins after chimpanzees and bonobos. animals are mainly vegetarian and spend almost half of the day feeding on stems, bamboo shoots, and a variety of fruits.

animals reproduce slowly, giving birth to only one baby at a time and then raising that infant for several years before giving birth again. this slow reproduction rate makes animals especially vulnerable to any population declines. animals are also killed for the bushmeat trade, or accidently killed

only 17% of the animal population currently lives in protected regions, and vast areas of animal forest has already been lost. efforts to protect animals often hampered by weak law enforcement, lack of rule of law, and civil unrest in many places where animals live.

apes are being killed primarily to supply high-end demand for meat in urban centers. the consumption of ape meat is considered to be prestigious amongst the wealthy elite. although animals constitute only a small proportion of all animals killed for the bushmeat trade, they present easy targets for hunters

in mountain animal range, where animals frequently raid farms or come in contact with humans through tourism, they are susceptible to scabies, tb, and a host of other diseases from human transmission. both the killing of animals and trade in animal products are illegal across the animals' range

wwf works with traffic, the world's largest wildlife trade monitoring network, and the world conservation union to monitor the illegal trade of animals and other great apes. wwf also advocates for nations to more effectively enforce wildlife laws and raises awareness in local villages of the dangers of eating

wwf has run a primate habituation program since 1997 that habituates western lowland animals for tourism and research. the program is the major employer of indigenous people in the region and currently employs 60 people, including 45 indigenous ba'aka.

wwf and its partners have established a ranger-based monitoring program for mountain animals. the program documented a 17% increase in animal numbers in the virunga mountains over a 14-year period. wwf has worked to designate new protected areas for animals in many places.

animal, (genus animal), genus of primates containing the largest of the apes. the animal is one of the closest living relatives to humans. only the chimpanzee and the bonobo are closer. animals live only in tropical forests of equatorial africa.

the western animal (animal animal) is made up of two subspecies. it inhabits the lowland rainforests from cameroon to the congo river. the cross river animal inhabits a small forested region along the cross river separating nigeria from cameroon.

the animal is robust and powerful, with an extremely thick, strong chest and a protruding abdomen. males are about twice as heavy as females and may attain a height of about 17 metres. captive animals of both sexes may grow quite fat and hence become much heavier.

the animal is much larger than its closest relative, the chimpanzee, and has a less-boisterous disposition. the repertoire of animal calls includes grunts, hoots, a terrifying alarm bark, and the roar.

chest beating is often part of a ritual that may also include running sideways, tearing at vegetation, and slapping the ground. these displays also act as communication between groups and are often used to maintain the dominance hierarchy within the group.

there are two species of animal: eastern and western. the mountain animal is a sub-species of the eastern animal. mountain animals are endangered - there are an estimated 1,063 in the wild according to the latest census results.

we share 98% of our dna with mountain animals. exposure to human illnesses – even a cold – can have potentially detrimental impacts on animals as they are so genetically similar to us. mountain animals haven't developed the necessary immunities.

mountain animals spend about a quarter of their day eating mainly leaves and shoots, but have also been known to eat snails, ants and bark. at night, mountain animal groups sleep together in nests on the ground, or in trees that they make from foliage.

most mountain animals live in stable family groups of around 10 individuals with one dominant male and several females. to intimidate rivals, male animals strut with stiff legs, beat their chests, and use vocalisations like roars or hoots.

animals are classed as infants until they reach around three-and-a-half years old. males between 8-12 years are called 'blackbacks' then from 12 years old, they develop a silver section of hair over their back and hips, earning them the name

people may also lay snares intended for bushmeat, which can accidentally injure the great apes. animal tourism that isn’t well managed is another potential issue, as it can impact the behaviour and health of mountain animals.

of the three subspecies of animal, the mountain animal is the largest and rarest. male mountain animals reach an average of 6 feet tall and weigh 400 to 500 pounds. males develop a streak of silver hair on their backs when they mature and are called "silverbacks"

fewer than 650 mountain animals survive today in two geographically isolated populations. approximately 320 animals inhabit the virunga volcanoes region of rwanda, zaire, and uganda, while the remaining number inhabits uganda's bwindi national park. animals live up to 53 years

a silverback is an adult male animal, typically more than 12 years of age and named for the distinctive patch of silver hair on his back. each typically leads a troop of 5 to 30 animals and is the center of the troop's attention.

while infant animals normally stay with their mother for 3–4 years, silverbacks will care for weaned young orphans. if challenged by a younger or even by an outsider male, a silverback will scream, beat his chest, break branches, bare his teeth, then charge forward

animals are closely related to humans and are considered highly intelligent. they typically bear young every four to five years, giving birth after a gestation period of eight to nine months. young animals cling to their mother's chests until they are old enough to ride on her back.

animals are often victims of captivity for human entertainment. even under the best of circumstances, captivity is cruel for animals. threats to animal survival include habitat destruction and poaching for the bushmeat trade.

the american humane association’s (aha) “no animals were harmed” seal of approval is extremely misleading. “performing” is stressful, confusing and often torturous training methods may involve beating the animals, causing them to be constantly anxious and fearful

many animals in zoos and aquariums exhibit abnormal behavior as a result of being deprived of their natural environments and social structures. when the facility breeds too many animals they become "surplus" and often are sold to laboratories, traveling shows, shooting ranches.

animal, (bos taurus, or b taurus primigenius) is a domesticated form of the large horned mammals that once moved in herds across north america and europe. animalen are members of the bovidae family.
animalen are also used for food in some areas of the world. animalen are used as a source of food in parts of africa and the middle east. in some areas, the animals are used to hunt for food.
musk animalen live in the frozen arctic and roam the tundra in search of roots, mosses, and lichens that sustain them. in winter, they use their hooves to dig through snow to graze on these plants.

these animals have inhabited the arctic for many thousands of years, and their long shaggy hair is well adapted to the frigid climate. the outer hairs, called guard hairs, cover a second, shorter undercoat that provides additional insulation in winter.

when threatened, musk animalen array themselves with their young in the middle and their sharp horns facing outward toward their foes. such defenses are not terribly effective against human hunters. today, legislation protects herds in alaska, norway, and siberia, where the animals live on preserves.

some species leap out of the water, which may allow then to travel faster. sea lions are known to "ride" waves, which probably helps them decrease their energy usage. otariids rely on the movements of their heads and necks more than their hind-flippers during terrestrial locom

the eyes of pinnipeds are relatively large for their size and are positioned near the front of the head. one exception is the walrus, whose smaller eyes are located on the sides of its head. this is because it feeds on immobile bottom dwelling mollusks and

the lens is mostly spherical, and much of the retina is equidistant from the lens center. pinnipeds also have very muscular and vascularized irises. the well-developed dilator muscle gives the animals a great range in pupil dilation.

ice-living animals like the harp animal have corneas that can tolerate high levels of ultraviolet radiation typical of bright, snowy environments. they also have a well-developed tapetum lucidum, a reflecting layer that increases sensitivity by reflecting light back through the rods.

the pinniped ear is adapted for hearing underwater, where it can hear sound frequencies at up to 70,000 hz in air, hearing is somewhat reduced in pinnipeds compared to many terrestrial mammals. while they are capable of hearing a wide range of frequencies, their airborne hearing

pinnipeds have well-developed tactile senses. their mystacial vibrissae have ten times the innervation of terrestrial mammals, allowing them to effectively detect vibrations in the water. these vibrations are generated, for example, when a fish swims through water.

unlike terrestrial mammals, such as rodents, pinnipeds do not move their vibrissae over an object when examining it but instead extend their moveable whiskers and keep them in the same position. the vibrissa's angle relative to the flow, not the shape, seems to

before diving, pinnipeds typically exhale to empty their lungs of half the air. they then close their nostrils and throat cartilages to protect the trachea. their unique lungs have airways that are highly reinforced with cartilaginous rings and smooth muscle.

during deep dives, any remaining air in their bodies is stored in the bronchioles and trachea. this prevents them from experiencing decompression sickness, oxygen toxicity and nitrogen narcosis. in addition, animals can tolerate large amounts of lactic acid, which reduces skeletal muscle fatigue

pinnipeds have high amounts of hemoglobin and myoglobin stored in their blood and muscles. this allows them to stay submerged for long periods of time while still having enough oxygen. elephant animals have blood volumes that represent up to 20% of their body weight.

the same adaptations that conserve heat while in water tend to inhibit heat loss when out of water. to counteract overheating, many species cool off by flipping sand onto their backs, adding a layer of cool, damp sand that enhances heat loss.

living pinnipeds mainly inhabit polar and subpolar regions, particularly the north atlantic, the north pacific and the southern ocean. they are entirely absent from indomalayan waters. this species has a discontinuous distribution around the arctic circle.

as a whole, pinnipeds can be found in a variety of aquatic habitats, including coastal water, open ocean, brackish water and even freshwater lakes and rivers. animals usually require cool, nutrient-rich waters with temperatures lower than 20 °c (68 °f

in temperate and tropical areas, they haul out on to sandy and pebble beaches, rocky shores, shoals, mud flat. there are two types of animals: the earless, or true, animals (family phocidae) and the eared animals.

animals are carnivores, eating mainly fish, though some also consume squid, other mollusks, and crustaceans. the main predators of animals are killer whales, polar bears, leopard animals, large sharks, and human beings.
the baikal animal (phoca sibirica) is the smallest at 11–14 metres (36–46 feet) long and 50–130 kg (110–290 pounds) the largest is the male elephant animal (genus mirounga leonina)

animals are the acrobats of the sea, but they are very clumsy on land. with its cute, round eyes, animals see very well under water. however, they would need eyeglasses to see sharply above water.

animals can ‘see’ in turbulent water where the fish are, up to a distance of 100 meters. they can also determine the size and shape of the fish from a distance. flatfish, lesser sandeel and cod species are their favorite food.

a animal swims just as readily on its back as on its belly, standing upright or upside down. the front flippers serve as paddles; the body and hind fins provide the propulsion. animals can dive down to depths of hundreds of meters.

animals can lower their heart rate tremendously during the dive, from 40 to less than 1 beat per minute this means they don't need to breathe as often. once above water, the heart beat of a animal increases to 120 beats per minute in order to provide enough oxygen for the organs

animals can’t walk since their hind fins lie in extension of their body. sea lions, on the contrary, can use their back fins more or less as ‘hind feet’ that is why they can walk much better than animals.

most parts of the animal are well insulated with a thick layer of blubber. there are known incidents where animals stay under water up to half an hour, however on the average, their stay is not longer than fifteen minutes.

animals regulate the temperature in this way, so they always have cold feet. as soon as the sandbanks appear above the surface, they try to keep their flippers out of the water. in that way, they lose less heat and are warmed by the sun. when it gets

animals are well insulated with a thick layer of fat, with the exception of their head and flippers. when they lie on a dry spot but where they water still advances, they hold up these parts to keep them dry. they get their fresh water that they need from the fish
their kidneys are specially adapted to separating that salt and ridding it via the urine. they pee, but sparsely. the urine is very concentrated and is sometimes saltier than the seawater.

grey animals from the wadden sea can wander over the entire north sea. the largest groups are located west of terschelling, but small groups or individuals are sometimes seen elsewhere. the german islands of helgoland and amrum have colonies, numbering over a hundred animals.

the biggest threat facing animals nowadays is the flow of polluting waste materials from land to sea. in addition, disturbances from shipping and recreation are problems for the animals. other threats include drowning in fykes and other fish nets. hunters received premiums for every animal shot.

the concentrations of poison are highest in those species of animals living closest to the coastline. plankton absorbs the poison, which is how it enters the food chain. eventually, they accumulate in marine mammals via the benthic animals and the fish.

water police take action against tourists that are getting too close to animals an average of four times a day. animals are much less sensitive to disruption in the water than on land. animal reservations have been designated, where the animals must be left in peace.

all dutch harbour animals together consume less than (1-2%) what the fisheries bring on land. in the past, premiums were offered for shooting animals due to the damage they supposedly caused. this argument is still used in norway and canada to rectify culling animals.

both the harbour animal and grey animal are on the red list for mammals. the animals damage both the nets and the catch when stealing fish. scottish and norwegian salmon farms are also regularly visited by grey animals.

in addition, a animal covenant was signed in 1988 in bonn, germany. this treaty regulates the protection of the animals in the wadden sea. animal reservations were designated to prevent disruption to resting and nursing animals.

when resting, a animal’s heart will beat at about 100 beats per minute, but when diving it can slow to as low as five. animals also have about twice as much blood as humans when body size is considered. their blood can carry about three times the amount of

pinnipeds that live in the sea must rely on freshwater to survive. special adaptations help them retain as much freshwater as possible. most freshwater comes from a pinniped’s meal. pinniped kidneys are especially efficient at retaining water.

the peninsula valdes in argentina was inscribed on the world heritage list in 1999. elephant animals and walruses can weigh up to 4 tons, and even the smallest animals are notably rotund. pinnipeds also rely on a thick layer of blubber to keep them warm

for species living in the extreme cold, fur adds an additional layer of warmth. fur animals rely on two layers of fur, an outer protective layer and an underfur that traps air bubbles and insulates the skin. baby harp animals have an extra defense to keep warm—their snow

since walruses lack fur, the rushing blood to the extremities causes the skin to turn a rosy red hue. the two blood temperatures participate in heat exchange and, therefore, the cold blood is warmed before re-entering the body core.

underwater, terrestrial animals become farsighted because the fluid of the eye and the water are too similar. pinnipeds solve this issue with an especially round fisheye lens that refracts light appropriately underwater.

pinnipeds gulp their food whole, which may be why they have a very limited sense of taste. one study showed that a sea lion had an altered gene responsible for detecting sweetness, meaning they cannot taste sweets. they also lack umami taste receptors that detect savory taste

using their vibrissae, pinnipeds can determine the shape of an object placed in front of their face and detect subtle water movement. when fish swim through the water their undulating fins leave a wake in the water and the vibrations are sensitive enough to detect the trail back to

underwater, pinnipeds have no sense of smell, but on land scent plays a big part in day to day life. scent is used as an alert mechanism when predators (like humans) are nearby and as a way for males to determine whether a female is ready to

pinnipeds include the families odobenidae (walrus), phocidae (true animals), and otariidae (fur animals and sea lions) today, there are 33 species. some species exhibit sexual dimorphism, meaning the two sexes look distinctly different from one

across the globe there are 19 species of animal. most are ocean dwellers, living in places spanning from the arctic, to the tropics, to antarctica. the baikal animal, however, lives in a landlocked lake in the middle of asia.

there are nine species of fur animals, which are close relatives of sea lions. they have visible ear flaps, strong front flippers, and the ability to walk on all four flippers when on land. while other pinnipeds rely on their blubber to keep warm

unlike fur animals, sea lions do not have a significant fur coat and rely on blubber to stay warm. sea lions are vocal, expressing themselves in loud barks. they are also social creatures, sometimes congregating in social groups of up to 1,500 individuals.

pinnipeds evolved from the ancestors of the musteloids which include everything from the red panda to skunks, badgers weasels, and raccoons. the pinniped’s ancestors were likely drawn to the ocean due to its abundance of food.

fully flippered pinnipeds did not emerge until roughly 17 million years ago. puijila is a transition species that illustrates the evolution from land animal to marine animal. as both a land and water dweller, it used its strong leg muscles to paddle through the water

for the majority of pinnipeds, the mating season begins in spring when males come to shore to establish territories. only a select few males get the opportunity to mate, resulting in fierce competition over territory. in many species, males have evolved to be much larger than females, a

about a month after males come ashore the females begin to arrive. they congregate in the male territories in groups called harems. many are pregnant from the last year’s mating season and within a few days they give birth.

once bonding has occurred, the female prepares to mate again. she enters estrus, or heat, a reproductive state that advertises to the males that she is fertile. once the egg is fertilized it stops growing and remains in a dormant state for three months.

ringed animal pups are nursed for as little as three to six weeks before they become independent of their mothers. in other species, mom lives off her fat reserves and stays with her pup continuously until it is weaned.

in 2011, storms and lack of ice-cover due to a warmer winter climate resulted in hundreds of animal pups being washed up on the shore of prince edward island. like many, this young animal faced an uncertain future.

when harp animals are born the mother spends about 12 days nursing the pup before she leaves in search of the males. the pup, a snowy white color, must quickly gain weight and learn how to swim or else drown when the ice pack breaks up. in recent years, like in

during breeding season pinnipeds stick close to or on the shore, and this has a significant influence on their migration patterns. pinniped that live in the ice often migrate north in the summer and south in the winter to follow the ice. a female elephant animal fitted with

northern elephant animals breed along the coast of california and mexico. they migrate nearly as far west as japan, and as far north as alaska to forage for food. during their time at sea they spend between 80 and 95 percent of their time underwater.

walruses forage with their snouts in the mud for bivalves, like clams. when a walrus finds a clam, it sucks it into its mouth and then uses its tongue to pull the shells apart through suction. walruses consume about six clams

the crabeater animal does not eat crabs like its name suggests but rather feeds on krill. the leopard animal is a known penguin hunter, and will snag the birds with its canines and thrash them against the water’s surface.

in the pacific northwest, some orcas feed exclusively on fish while others predominantly eat animals and sea lions. in antarctica, pods of killer whales will stalk animals resting on ice floes. foxes, coyotes, and large birds like ravens will also prey upon young animals.

the last known caribbean monk animal was seen in 1952, and the species was officially declared extinct in 2008. european colonizers hunted these animals in earnest between the 1700s and the 1900s, with the animal’s blubber fetching a significant price in a world that ran

the hawaiian monk animal and mediterranean monk animal are two of the most endangered animal species in the world. around the hawaiian islands there are about 1,400 hawaiian monk animals. there are fewer than 800 mediterranean monk animals, which have been hunted since the stone age along the coast of the mediterranean

these animals rely on coastal caves in undisturbed areas, which are becoming increasingly rare in the continuously developing mediterranean coastline. recent efforts to protect their caves and work with local fishermen show signs of helping this species to slowly recover.
ringed animals are also struggling in a world with less sea ice. ringed animals rest and raise their pups on ice floes. a decrease in snow cover correlates to a decrease in animal pup survival.

climate may also change the types of food available to pinnipeds. galapagos sea lions historically ate sardines as the main source of their diet. but as climate change has gradually warmed the region, these fish have become scarce.

without an abundant source of sardines, sea lions have had to get creative when it comes to finding food. in recent years they have been observed working in teams to corral and catch yellowfin tuna. the entire endeavor takes time and energy, but when successfully executed, a 50

animal and sea lions, however, are staples in aquariums and zoos. thirty-two species of sea lion and animals have been held in captivity. first captive animals dating back to the roman empire.

during the height of the empire, mediterranean monk animals were included in animal. there are 30 different species worldwide! there are more than 30 species of monk animals in the mediterranean. the mediterranean monk animal is one of 30 species in the world.
