animal vocalizations consist of grunts, barks, growls, chirps, and whistles to communicate their thoughts and feelings. they are inquisitive, social, and communicative mammals with a penchant for both the land and sea.
all pinnipeds occupy the order of carnivora — the same order as cats, bears, canids, raccoons, skunks, and mongooses. the name pinniped is aptly chosen, since it means “fin-footed” in latin

the pinnipeds fall into three broad families. together, these three families account for a total of 32 or 33 living species, plus several subspecies. fifty more extinct species have been documented from either recent history or the fossil record.

the walrus diverges from both families and can be identified by its large tusks, smaller eyes, especially prominent whiskers, and almost completely hairless bodies. elephant animal males have an elongated nose that aids them during mating and reproduction.

the pinniped’s most important innovation is the flipper. it allows them to cut gracefully through the water to catch prey and avoid predators. the flipper is an excellent example of convergent evolution in mammals. the cetaceans, animals, and sea cows

true animals move their hind limbs and lower body from side to side for continuous propulsion, while their forelimbs are used to help them maneuver. eared animals are more like penguins and sea turtles. they use their front limbs for propulsion in a sort of discontinuous rowing motion

although pinnipeds cannot match the top speed of some aquatic animals, their greatest advantage in the water is their flexibility despite their size, their smooth, streamlined bodies can execute sharp turns on a dime. some species of these animals can even bend their bodies almost completely backwards.

after extended periods at sea, pinnipeds will return to land or sea ice for mating, births, molting, or safety. here they tend to congregate in large groups, which are known as herds or pods (depending on the species)

these animals are widespread along the coasts and open oceans of every continent on the earth, including antarctica. they prefer the cold, nutrient-rich waters of the world. pinnipeds inhabit saltwater regions almost exclusively, but they do swim up rivers and estuaries to hunt for

the pinniped diet is best described as eclectic. although fish is the most common part of their diet, these animals are also known to feed on squid, octopus, lobsters, and eels when given the opportunity.
despite their size, animals make a tempting target for orcas, sharks, bears, and other large and ferocious predators. see all of our entertaining and insightful animal articles at cnn.com/animals.

young pups and lone adults are the most likely to be the target of a hungry predator. animals ward off predators by congregating in large groups together. hissing, teeth chattering, and aggressive visual displays are exhibited as a warning.

climate change looms as the most significant disruption to the animal’s natural habitat. as sea ice melts, arctic animals may lose their natural breeding grounds. their physiology is also a poor fit for warming waters.

males fight for the opportunity to mate by biting or hitting each other. the mother’s milk contains mostly fat rather than lactose, so once the pup is finally born, it can grow quickly and begin to fend for itself.

animal populations were once on the brink, but they have begun to recover thanks to the efforts of the worldwide conservation community. a study from frontiers in ecology and evolution estimates that these species have recovered from a minimum population of 100 to at least 100,000 in 70 years.

the caribbean monk animal went extinct sometime in the mid 20th century. animals may attempt to defend their territory, so it is a good idea to avoid disturbing them. scientists believe that the pinnipeds likely descended from a single ancestral line.

puijila resembled a small carnivorous mammal with webbed feet 20 to 24 million years ago in freshwater habitation. another fossil known as enaliarctos more closely resembles modern animals with their marine specialization.

predators of animals include humans, sharks, and killer whales. the scientific name for the animal is phoca vitulina. the average litter size for a animal is 1. there are 30 different animal species worldwide.

the animal (pan troglodytes), also known as the common animal, or simply chimp, is a species of great ape native to the forest and savannah of tropical africa. it has four confirmed subspecies and a fifth proposed subspecies. the animal

it is larger and more robust than the bonobo, weighing 40–70 kg. its gestation period is eight months. the infant is weaned at about three years old, but usually maintains a close relationship with its mother for several years more.

the animal is listed on the iucn red list as an endangered species. between 170,000 and 300,000 individuals are estimated across its range. the biggest threats to the animal are habitat loss, poaching, and disease.

etymology, genetics, taxonomy and genetics, biology, and evolution are all mentioned in the opening of this article. the following is a list of some of the most important words used in the english language.

the first great ape known to western science in the 17th century was the "orang-outang" (genus pongo) in 1641, the dutch anatomist nicolaes tulp applied the name to a animal or bonobo brought to the netherlands from angola

german naturalist johann friedrich blumenbach classified the animal as simia troglodytes by 1775 another german naturalist, lorenz oken, coined the genus pan in 1816. existing animal populations in west and central africa do not overlap with the major

dna evidence suggests the bonobo and animal species separated from each other less than one million years ago. a 2017 genetic study suggests ancient gene flow (introgression) between 200 and 550 thousand years ago from the bonobo into the ancestors of central and eastern animals. the animal

four subspecies of the animal have been recognised with the possibility of a fifth. two juvenile central animals, the nominate subspecies, are the nominee subspecies. there are about 140,000 central animals existing in the wild.

southeastern animal, p troglodytes marungensis, in burundi, rwanda, tanzania, and uganda. colin groves argues that this is a subspecies, created by enough variation between the northern and southern populations of p t schweinfurthii

in december 2003, a preliminary analysis of 7600 genes shared between the two genomes confirmed that certain genes, such as the forkhead-box p2 transcription factor which is involved in speech development, have undergone rapid evolution in the human lineage. a draft version of the animal genome was

adult animals have an average standing height of 150 cm (4 ft 11 in) wild adult males weigh between 40 and 70 kg (88 and 154 lb) with females weighing between 27 and 50 kg (60 and 110 lb) in exceptional cases, certain individuals may considerably exceed these measurements,

a animal's head is rounded with a prominent and prognathous face. the hands have long fingers with short thumbs and flat fingernails. the feet are adapted for grasping, the big toe being opposable. the pelvis is long with an extended ilium.

the hair of a animal is typically black but can be brown or ginger. as they get older, white or grey patches may appear, particularly on the chin and lower region. the skin may range from pale to dark, and females develop swelling pink skin when in oestrus.

the grip strength of an adult animal is estimated to be 200 kg (441 lb) it lives in a variety of habitats, including dry savanna, evergreen rainforest, montane forest, swamp forest and dry woodland-savanna mosaic. in gombe, the chimpan

the animal has an advanced cognitive map of its home range and can repeatedly find food. it prefers fruit above all other food items but also eats leaves and leaf buds, seeds, blossoms, stems, pith, bark and resin.

5% of chimp feeding time concentrated on fruits (846% of which being ripe), particularly those from two species of ficus. 19% of feeding time was spent on arboreal leaves, mostly broussonetia papyrifera and celtis mildbraed

animals do not appear to directly compete with gorillas in areas where they overlap. when fruit is abundant gorilla and animal diets converge, but when fruit is scarce gorillas resort to vegetation. female animals appear to consume much less animal flesh than males.

the average lifespan of a animal in the wild is relatively short, usually less than 15 years. wild individuals may live over 25 years and on rare occasions, around 60 years. captive animals tend to live longer, with median lifespans of 31 years.

the oldest known male captive animal lived to 66 years. the oldest female, little mama, was over 70 years old. animals may react to a leopard's presence with loud vocalising, branch shaking and throwing objects. there is at least one record of animals killing a

animals and humans share only 50% of their parasite and microbe species. this is due to the differences in environmental and dietary adaptations. human internal parasite species overlap more with omnivorous, savanna-dwelling baboons.

animals live in communities that typically range from around 20 to more than 150 members. the most prevalent species was the protozoan troglodytella abrassarti. recent studies have suggested that human observers influence animal behaviour.

at the core of social structures are males, which patrol the territory, protect group members, and search for food. males remain in their natal communities, while females generally emigrate at adolescence. males in a community are more likely to be related to one another than females are to each

individual animals often forage for food alone, or in smaller groups as opposed to the much larger "parent" group. top-ranking males tend to be aggressive even during dominance stability. this is probably due to the animal's fission-fusion society.

males maintain and improve their social ranks by forming coalitions, which have been characterised as "exploitative" and are based on an individual's influence in agonistic interactions. being in a coalition allows males to dominate a third individual when they could not by themselves.

low-ranking males benefit from an unstable hierarchy and often find increased sexual opportunities if a dispute or conflict occurs. while animal social structure is often referred to as patriarchal, it is not entirely unheard of for females to forge coalitions against males.

animals have been described as highly territorial and will frequently kill other animals. social grooming appears to be important in the formation and maintenance of coalitions. it is more common among adult males than adult females and between males and females.

animals mate throughout the year, although the number of females in oestrus varies seasonally in a group. there are confirmed cases of adult males safely integrating themselves into new communities among west african animals.

animals are promiscuous; during oestrus, females mate with several males in their community. oestrous females exhibit sexual swellings. infanticide has been recorded in animal communities in some areas.

a animal's future rank may be dependent on its mother's status. newborn animals are helpless; their grasping reflex is not strong enough to support them for more than a few seconds. mothers provide their young with food, warmth, and protection.

this article is about the animal family (sciuridae) as a whole. for other uses, see animal (disambiguation)animals are members of the family sciuridae, a family that includes small or medium-size rodents.

animals are indigenous to the americas, eurasia, and africa, and were introduced by humans to australia. the earliest known fossilized animals date from the eocene epoch. animals are most closely related to the mountain beaver and the dormice.

[4] the old english word is of common germanic origin, cognates of which are still used in other germanic languages, including the german eichhörnchen. a group of animals is called a "dray" or a "scurry"

animals typically have slender bodies with very long very bushy tails and large eyes. in general, their fur is soft and silky, though much thicker in some species than others. in most animal species, the hind limbs are longer than the fore limbs.

animals live in almost every habitat, from tropical rainforest to semiarid desert. they are predominantly herbivorous, subsisting on seeds and nuts, but many will eat insects and even small vertebrates.
many juvenile animals die in the first year of life. adult animals can have a lifespan of 5 to 10 years in the wild. some can survive 10 to 20 years in captivity.

animals mate either once or twice a year and, following a gestation period of three to six weeks, give birth to a number of offspring. a special quality of animal tail hair is that it is all guard hairs, not undercoat.

in most species of animal, the female alone looks after the young, which are weaned at six to ten weeks and become sexually mature by the end of their first year. ground animals and tree animals are usually either diurnal or crepuscular, while the flying animal

because animals cannot digest cellulose, they must rely on foods rich in protein, carbohydrates, and fats. early spring is the hardest time of year for animals because the nuts they buried are beginning to sprout. animals, being primarily herbivores, eat a wide variety

animals, like pigeons and other fauna, are synanthropes, in that they benefit and thrive from their interaction in human environments. this gradual process of successful interaction is called synurbanization, wherein animals lose their inherent fear of humans in an urban environment.

animal attacks on humans are exceedingly rare, but do occur. at least 10% of the stomachs of white-tailed antelope animals contained vertebrate, mostly lizards and rodents. a pack of black animals killed and ate a large stray dog in lazo, russia.

the living animals are divided into five subfamilies, with about 58 genera and some 285 species. the oldest animal fossil, hesperopetes, dates back to the chadronian (late eocene, about 40–35 million years ago)

the three main lineages are the ratufinae (oriental giant animals), sciurillinae and all other subfamilies. the third lineage, by far the largest, has a near-cosmopolitan distribution. this further supports the hypothesis that the common ancestor

the sciurinae contains the flying animals (pteromyini) and the sciurini, which among others contains the american tree animals. two of the three subfamilies are of about equal size, containing between nearly 70 and 80 species each. the third is

the largest subfamily, the xerinae, is made up from the mainly terrestrial (ground-living) forms. they include the large marmots and the popular prairie dogs, among others, as well as the tree animals of africa. they tend to be more g

the tiniest animal is the aptly named african pygmy animal, only five inches long from nose to tail. the indian giant animal is three feet long. more than 200 animal species live all over the world, with the notable exception of australia.

tree animals are the types most commonly recognized, often seen gracefully scampering and leaping from branch to branch. other species are ground animals that live in burrow or tunnel systems, where some hibernate during the winter season.

flying animals are a third, adaptable type of animal. they live something like birds do, in nests or tree holes, and although they do not fly, they can really move across the sky. they eat nuts and fruit, but also catch insects and even baby birds.
mothers may have several litters in a year, so most animal populations are robust. most animal populations in the u.s. are robust, according to the american animal association.

the rounded ears, small in relation to body size, are densely covered with short, fine hairs, which form a long tuft at the tips of the ears in some species. claws are large, strong, curved, and very sharp, which enables tree animals to navigate vertical

four species of oriental giant animals (genus ratufa) native to the tropical forests of southeast asia are the largest. two species of pygmy animals are the smallest, with a body length of 9 to 12 cm and an equally long tail.

all tree animals are diurnal and arboreal, but the range of vertical activity in species differs widely. some species are striped along the sides and back; sometimes the head is also striped. tropical species exhibit combinations of white, gray, yellow, orange, red, maroon

some large tropical animals nest at middle levels but travel and forage low in the understory or on the ground. certain species, such as the red-tailed animal (s granatensis) of the american tropics and the african pygmy animal, are active from ground

most tree animals have strong chisel-like incisors and powerful jaws. they also eat seeds, fungi, insects and other arthropods. thomas’s rope animal (funisciurus anerythrus) of africa even submerges itself and swims underwater

nests are constructed among branches in the forest canopy or at lower levels in tree crowns, vine tangles, tree hollows, or undergrowth near the ground. some species of tropical tree animals produce several litters per year. breeding season in the northern hemisphere may extend from

east of the asian continental margin, tree animals inhabit the forests of taiwan, some islands in the philippines, and sulawesi. they do not occur naturally anywhere east of those islands. most of the species in 20 of the 22 genera are found in tropical rainforests.

2 subfamilies comprising 272 species in 51 genera found worldwide. see flying animal for 15 genera and 42 species of subfamily pteromyinae. ground animals (10 genera, 62 species), marmots (1 genus, 14 species), chipmunks
urus (red animals or chickarees) or rope (african striped animals) rope. rope, or african striped, animals. rops. robes. roves. ropsy. rop. rove. roving roves roves
genus rubrisciurus (sulawesi giant animal) is a southeast asian species. genus nannosciurus is a black-eared animal.genus glyphotes is an asian species found only on borneo.

animals are nimble, bushy-tailed rodents found all over the world. they belong to the sciuridae family, which includes prairie dogs, chipmunks and marmots. there are more than 200 species of animals, according to the integrated taxonomic
the indian giant animal is the world's largest known animal. it grows to 36 inches (1 meter) long and weighs up to 4 pounds (18 kilograms) american red animals feed on the seeds of evergreen trees.

animals typically weigh about 1 to 15 pounds (045 to 068 kg) they are very territorial and will fight to the death to defend their area. tree animals typically live in wooded areas, since they prefer to live in trees.

albino animals are quite popular in some parts of the united states. they dig burrows, a system of tunnels underground, to live in. some animals also hibernate in burrows during the winter to keep warm.

flying animals make their homes in tree holes or nests that are built into the crooks of branches. they can glide up to 160 feet (48 m), making it look like they can fly. on average, animals eat about one pound of food per week.

animals mainly eat fungi, seeds, nuts and fruits, but they will also munch on eggs, small insects, caterpillars, small animals and even young snakes. a female carries her young for a gestation period of 29 to 65 days, depending on the size of the

a boost of stress during pregnancy helps red animals ensure that their pups will grow fast. after seven to eight weeks, the young are weaned. when the kits leave the nest, they don't travel farther than 2 miles from home.

animals have four teeth in the front of their mouth that constantly grow throughout their lives. this ensures that their teeth don't wear down to nubs from gnawing on nuts and other objects. animals can run 20 mph (32 kph)
animals bury their acorns, but forget where they put them. the forgotten acorns become oak trees. it comes in a variety of colors, such as white, gray, brown and black.

gray and red animals are common in massachusetts. learn about their food habitat, and behavior and get tips for dealing with problem animals. both are members of the animal family, along with flying animals, chipmunks, and woodchucks.

gray animals use leaf nests and natural cavities for shelter and for rearing the young. red animals are small- to medium-sized tree-climbing animals. adults are between 105 and 15 inches long with tails averaging 35–6 inches.

gray animals usually breed at 10–14 months of age yearlings have only one litter per year but adults may breed twice annually. winter breeding occurs in january to february and summer breeding from may to july. red animals tend to prefer tree leaf nests over cavities.

red animals are opportunistic, but most commonly feed on conifer seeds. they also eat fungi, buds, and the inner bark of trees, and occasionally nuts, seeds, fruits, grains, insect larvae, and bird nestlings.

gray animals are tolerant of human presence and often live in urban or suburban areas with large, mature shade trees. juveniles establish home ranges on, or adjacent to, that of their mother. they are territorial and defend their areas against other red animals.

animals can enter attics, crawl spaces, or sheds for nesting or shelter. a small dome or cage of chicken wire placed over individual plants or small rows can protect plants until they get large enough to be uninteresting to the animals.

commercial taste repellents can be applied to seeds, bulbs, flowers, shrubs, fences, and siding to discourage animals. do not use d-con® or other similar products as these are formulated for and are legal only for use on rats and mice inside buildings.

traps may be effective in removing animals within an attic or other confined space. any trapped animal must either be relocated on the premises (within the property) or destroyed humanely. shooting is quick, simple, and effective in areas where firearm discharge is safe and legal.

there are more than 200 species of animals all over the world. they are mostly categorized into three different types – ground animals, tree animals and flying animals. animals are found on every continent except antarctica and australia.

a animal is a very intelligent animal and rodent, using different sounds to communicate with other animals. animals do not like some smells and are repellent towards them, like white pepper, garlic, and black pepper.

see all of our entertaining and insightful animal articles. the word sciuridae is from the latin word sciurus, which means animal. the latin root comes from a combination of two greek words – skia (shade) and oura (tail)

most species have small yet pointed ears with tiny, sharp claws, giving them the leverage that they need to climb trees quickly. the smallest animal is only 10 cm long while some of the largest animals in the world can have bodies of 30 to 50 cm in size.

the indian giant animal is about 11 kg, featuring beautiful rust and black fur coat. these rodents are warm and fuzzy animals, easily giving over their trust to humans. they are also very intelligent, and their brain is known to be dedicated to visual functions.

to warn others of impending danger or potential suspicion, these rodents will wag their tails. they are also known to be noisy animals and vocalize their thoughts by chattering, barking, purring, and screaming – especially during mating season.

these animals are most active during the day and during the dawn and at dusk. they do not like the smell of white pepper, black pepper, and garlic, giving you an easy and non-toxic repellent to keep these critters away.

tree animals especially live in wooded areas and (as their name suggests) prefer living in the trees. ground animals live on the ground, digging tunnels and burros to travel underground. these burrows are also used to hibernate and nest during the winter season.

animals primarily eat seeds, nuts, fungi, and fruit apart from that they also feed on other plant matter. some species are also omnivorous in times when food is not plentiful. they either make open nests that are used for sleeping or covered ones.
these animals are primarily herbivorous, consuming seeds, nuts, fruit, and fungi. when they need to round out their diet, they’ll seek out the eggs of other animals for an omnivorous diet.
animal reproduction, babies, and lifespanthese animals breed once or twice every year they have a gestation period of 3 to 6 weeks. large carnivorous birds like eagles also prey on animals.
there are more than 200 species of animals around the world. most of them can be divided up by their method of travel. a baby is known to thrive most easily when they have the care of their mothers.

while the usual diet of a animal is made up of nuts, seeds, and fruits, some of them are also omnivorous and can eat eggs, insects, and other small vertebrates when the food is scarce. animals belong to the kingdom animalia.
animals eat fruit, seeds, and insects. the average number of babies a animal has is 3. the main predators of animals include snakes, coyotes, and weasels. animals live in woodlands and dense forests.

animals are repellent towards smells of white pepper, black pepper, and garlic – they find them very unpleasant. a animal can travel at speeds of up to 16 miles per hour. animal poop largely resembles rat poop.

animals are affectionate and are very trusting if they trust you, they can come to eat from your hand as well. however, whether or not they are dangerous is unclear. some say that they do carry diseases that they can pass to humans.
animal is a member of the family rhinocerotidae. it is one of the five extant species (or numerous extinct species) of odd-toed ungulates in the family.

by weight, rhino horns cost as much as gold on the black market, making it novel for criminal and illegal poachers. however, the horns are made of keratin, the same type of protein that makes up hair and fingernails, which have null medicinal properties.

the iucn red list identifies the black, javan, and sumatran animal as critically endangered. demand was driven from sudden wealth, and medicinal misinformation. both african species have two horns, while the indian and javan have a single horn.
the word animal is derived through latin from the ancient greek:  ῥῑνά (rhino, "nose") and  κέρα (keras, "horn") with a horn on the nose.

an adult black animal stands 150–175 m (59–69 in) high at the shoulder and is 35–39 m (11–13 ft) in length. an adult weighs from 850 to 1,600 kg (1,870 to 3,530 lb)

the indian animal has a single horn 20 to 60 cm long. it is nearly as large as the african white rhino. its thick, silver-brown skin folds into the shoulder, back, and rump, giving it an armored appearance.

indian rhinos once inhabited many areas ranging from pakistan to myanmar and maybe even parts of china. because of human influence, they now exist in only several protected areas of india and nepal. they are confined to the tall grasslands and forests in the foothills of the himalayas.

the javan animal (animal sondaicus) is one of the most endangered large mammals in the world. according to 2015 estimates, only about 60 remain, in java, indonesia, all in the wild. it is also the least known rhino species

4–32 m (7 ft 10 in–10 ft 6 in) and weighs around 700 kg (1,500 lb) the largest individuals have been known to weigh as much as 1,000 kilograms (2,200 lb) like the african species, it has two horns;

animal horns are used in traditional medicines in parts of asia, and for dagger handles in yemen and oman. hunting licenses for five namibian black rhinos are auctioned annually. the money goes to the government's game products trust fund.

it is a common misconception that animal horn in powdered form is used as an aphrodisiac or a cure for cancer. in traditional chinese medicine (tcm), rhino horn is sometimes prescribed for fevers and convulsions.

in 2011, the register of chinese herbal medicine issued a formal statement condemning the use of animal horn. a growing number of tcm educators are also speaking out against the practice. some tcm practitioners still believe that it is a life-saving medicine.

the original idea grew out of research into the horn as a reservoir for one-time tick treatments. experts selected an acaricide they think is safe for the rhino, oxpeckers, vultures, and other animals in the preserve's ecosystem.

save the rhino questions the feasibility of applying the technique to all african rhinos, since workers would have to reapply the acaricide every 4 years. one out of 150 rhinos treated did not survive the anesthesia.

greek historian and geographer agatharchides (2nd century bc) mentions the animal in his book on the erythraean sea. albrecht dürer created a famous woodcut of a rhino in 1515, based on a written description

there are legends about animales stamping out fire in burma, india, and malaysia. there are no recent confirmations of this phenomenon. this legend was depicted in the film the gods must be crazy (1980)

animal is any of five or six species of giant horn-bearing herbivores that include some of the largest living land mammals. only african and asian elephants are taller at the shoulder than the two largest rhinocero species.

the total population of all animal species combined is probably fewer than 30,000. animales today are restricted to eastern and southern africa and to subtropical and tropical asia. all but one of the surviving species are endangered.

modern rhinos are large animals, ranging from 25 metres (8 feet) long and 15 metres (5 feet) high at the shoulder in the sumatran animal. adults of larger species weigh 3–5 tons. animales are noted for their thick

animales are by far the largest of the perissodactyls, an order of hoofed mammals that also includes the horses and zebras one of the features of very large body size in mammals is a low reproductive rate. in rhinocer

the three asian species fight with their razor-sharp lower outer incisor teeth, not with their horns. in indian animales such teeth, or tusks, can reach 13 cm (5 inches) in length among dominant males. the african species, in contrast

powdered animal horn has been a highly sought commodity in traditional chinese medicine. substitute agents have been found, particularly pig bone and water buffalo horn. rhino horn commands tens of thousands of dollars per kilogram in asian markets.
the largest land mammal ever to have lived was not an elephant but a perissodactyl. indricotherium was 6 metres (20 feet) long and could browse treetops like a giraffe.

rhinos once roamed many places throughout europe, asia, and africa and were known to early europeans who depicted them in cave paintings. at the beginning of the 20th century, 500,000 rhinos roamed africa and asia. by 1970, rhino numbers dropped to 70,

a small population of javan rhinos is found in only one national park on the northern tip of the indonesian island of java. successful conservation efforts have led to an increase in the number of greater one-horned (or indian) rhinos, from around 200 at the turn

the only two remaining northern white rhino are kept under 24-hour guard in ol pejeta conservancy in kenya. black rhinos have doubled in number over the past two decades from their low point of fewer than 2,500 individuals. but total numbers are still a fraction of

rhinos date back millions of years to the miocene era, but they are also mammals like us. there are two species of african rhinos, the white rhino and black rhino, and each is distinct in its own way. both rhinos have two horns.

in the wild, the adult black or white rhino has no predators except for humans rhinos are hunted and killed for their horns. the major demand for rhino horn is in asia, where it is used in ornamental carvings and traditional medicine.

african wildlife foundation is working with other conservation organizations and governments to spread public awareness about the illegal rhino horn trade. their horns are not true horns; they are actually made of keratin. rhino horn is as effective at curing cancer as chewing on your fingernails.

awf constructed nguila rhino sanctuary in tsavo east national park in kenya. awf provided funding to the sanctuary, ensured park staff had necessary equipment (vehicles, radio sets, etc), and created housing for rangers.

in 2012, awf hosted a rhino summit to create a comprehensive plan to protect rhinos. the plan called for increasing surveillance on the ground, strengthening law enforcement, curbing demand and trade, and reaching out to influence policy makers.

rhinos live in home ranges that can sometimes overlap with each other. their feeding grounds, wallows, and water holes may be shared. the black rhino is usually solitary, while the white rhino tends to be more social.

the african rhino is divided into two species, the black rhino and the white rhino. white rhinos mainly live in south africa, but they have also been reintroduced to botswana, namibia, swaziland, and zimbabwe. southern white rhinos have been introduced

animales are large, herbivorous mammals identified by their characteristic horned snouts. there are five species and 11 subspecies of rhino; some have two horns, while others have one. their horns are sometimes sold as trophies or decorations, but more often they

poaching and loss of habitat have put all rhino species in danger of extinction. today, the group says, there are 29,000 rhinos in the wild. there are 5,055 black rhinos, fewer than 100 sumatran rhinos and only 35 to 44 j

there are 3,333 greater one-horned rhinos in the world. the total population estimate in 2007 was 2,575 individuals, according to the iucn. the northern white rhino is considered "extinct" in the wild.

there are now only two northern white rhinos left in the world, both living in captivity, according to the world wildlife fund. they live in the ol pejeta conservancy in kenya. on march 20, 2018, the conservancy announced the death of the last male northern white

with natural breeding attempts nixed for the northern white rhinos, conservationists have turned to in vitro fertilization. ivf in these animales comes with its own set of challenges, including figuring out how to get immature eggs to develop outside of the female's body.

rhino horns are made of keratin, which is also the key component of human hair and fingernails. ct scans have shown dense mineral deposits of calcium and melanin in the core of the horn. the calcium makes the horn stronger, and the melanin protects it from the
black rhinos, white rhinos and sumatran rhinos have two horns. rhino horns tend to curve backward, toward the head. the outside of the horn is rather soft and can be worn down or sharpened.

the largest rhino species is the white rhino, according to the san diego zoo. the greater one-horned rhino's horn is 8 to 24 inches (20 to 61 cm), and javan rhinos have a horn that is about 10 inches (25 cm) long

white rhinos and black rhinos live in the grasslands and floodplains of eastern and southern africa. greater one-horned rhinos can be found in the swamps and rain forests of northern india and southern nepal. sumatran and javan rhinos are found only

animales are herbivores, which means they eat only vegetation. this is because their snouts are different shapes to accommodate different types of food. the black rhino eats trees or bushes because its long lips allow it to pick leaves and fruit from up high.

every two and a half to five years, a female rhino will reproduce. female rhinos carry their young for a gestation period of 15 to 16 months. baby rhinos, which are called calves, are still quite big, at 88 to 140 lbs (40 to 64 kg)
fewer than 250 sumatran rhinos (dicerorhinus sumatrensis) are left in the wild. javan rhinos: animal unicornis (also called indian rhino)

black rhinos are not actually black, according to the international rhino foundation. they probably got that name from the dark, muddy soil they like to wallow in. poachers also value rhino horns for making ornamental dagger handles.
jambiyas can be made from precious metal, buffalo hide or plastic. those made from rhino horn were considered the "rolex" version. the woolly rhino died out about 10,000 years ago.

our planet is home to five species of animal. the black rhino and the white rhino live in africa. the sumatran, javan and indian (or greater one-horned) rhino inhabit the tropical forests and swamps of asia.

the largest of the five species is the white rhino, which can grow to 18m tall and weigh a massive 2,500kg – that’s the weight of 30 men! despite their huge size and strength, these bulky beasts don’t prey on other animals for

some species, particularly the white rhino, may live in a group, known as a ‘crash’ these crashes are usually made up of a female and her calves, although sometimes adult females (called cows) can be seen together, too.

animal                from wikipedia, the free encyclopedia.jump to navigationjump to search                "bunny" redirects here for other uses, see bunny (disambiguation) and animal (dis abbreviation) animal is a small european animal in the family leporidae.

the european animal is familiar throughout the world as a wild prey animal and as a domesticated form of livestock and pet. sylvilagus includes 13 wild animal species, among them the seven types of cottontail.

male animals are called bucks; females are called does. an older term for an adult animal used until the 18th century is coney (derived ultimately from the latin cuniculus) animal once referred only to the young animals.

animals and hares were formerly classified in the order rodentia (rodent) until 1912, when they were moved into a new order, lagomorpha (which also includes pikas) the word animal itself derives from the middle english rabet, a borrowing

a small, round, dust-coloured animal with upright, close-set ears sat on the ground amidst dead branches. a model of a relatively large animal, with a slightly longer face and shorter, rounder ears, and fur patterned black and gold.

a animal is a medium-sized animal with light brown fur ticked with grey, its ears large and upright. hares are precocial, born relatively mature and mobile with hair and good vision, while animals are altricial, born hairless and blind, and requiring closer care

hares have not been domesticated, while descendants of the european animal are commonly bred as livestock and kept as pets. hares are generally larger than animals, with ears that are more elongated and with hind legs that are larger and longer.

domestic animals in modern times range in size from dwarf to giant animal fur, prized for its softness, can be found in a broad range of coat colors and patterns. the earliest breeds were important sources of meat, and so became larger than wild animals.

carl linnaeus originally grouped animals and rodents under the class glires; later, they were separated as the scientific consensus is that many of their similarities were a result of convergent evolution. recent dna analysis and the discovery of a common ancestor has supported the view that they do share a

most wild animals (especially compared to hares) have relatively full, egg-shaped bodies. the soft coat of the wild animal is agouti in coloration (or, rarely, melanistic), which aids in camouflage. the tail of the animal (with the exception of the

the anatomy of animals' hind limbs are structurally similar to that of other land mammals and contribute to their specialized form of locomotion. the bones of the hind limbs consist of long bones (the femur, tibia, fibula, and phalanges) as well as short

animals stay just on their toes when moving; this is called digitigrade locomotion. this allows them to produce their hopping form of locomotion longer hind limbs are more capable of producing faster speeds. hares, which have longer legs than cottontail animals

the hind limbs of a animal are an exaggerated feature. they are much longer than the forelimbs, providing more force. animals that generate less force, putting less stress on bones are more prone to osteoporosis due to bone rarefaction.

the muscles of animal's hind limbs can be classified into four main categories: hamstrings, quadriceps, dorsiflexors, or plantar flexors. for example, hares have a greater resistance to fatigue than cottontails. some animals can adjust their ears to

in the family leporidae, the ears are typically longer than they are wide. evolution has favored animals having shorter ears so the larger surface area does not cause them to lose heat in more temperate regions. the opposite can be seen in animals that live in hotter climates, mainly because

the animal is characterized by its shorter ears while hares are characterized by their longer ears. animals' ears are an important structure to aid thermoregulation and detect predators due to how the outer, middle, and inner ear muscles coordinate with one another. it is theorized that

the middle ear is filled with three bones called ossicles and is separated by the outer eardrum in the back of the animal's skull. the three ossicle are called hammer, anvil, and stirrup and act to decrease sound before it hits the inner ear.

thermoregulation is the process that an organism utilizes to maintain an optimal body temperature independent of external conditions. this process is carried out by the pinnae which takes up most of the animal's body surface and contain a vascular network and arteriovenous shunts. in a

constriction and dilation of blood vessels in the ears are used to control the core body temperature of a animal. if the core temperature exceeds its optimal temperature greatly, blood flow is constricted to limit the amount of blood going through the vessels.

the animal has the capability to stretch its pinnae which allows for greater surface area and increase heat dissipation. in cold winters, the animal does the opposite and folds its ears in order to decrease its surface area to the ambient air which would decrease their body temperature.

the animal's nasal cavity lies dorsal to the oral cavity, and the two compartments are separated by the hard and soft palate. the nasal cavity itself is separated into a left and right side by a cartilage barrier, and it is covered in fine hairs that trap dust before it can

the trachea is a long tube embedded with cartilaginous rings that prevent the tube from collapsing as air moves in and out of the lungs. the branching that is typically found in animal lungs is a clear example of monopodial branching, in which smaller branches divide out later

animals lungs are divided into four lobes: the cranial, middle, caudal, and accessory lobes. the epiglottis functions to prevent the animal from aspirating on its food. the presence of a soft and hard palate allow the animal to breathe through

animals are herbivores that feed by grazing on grass and other leafy plants. their diet contains large amounts of cellulose, which is hard to digest. animals solve this problem via a form of hindgut fermentation.

animals graze heavily and rapidly for roughly the first half-hour of a grazing period. in this time, the animal will also excrete many hard fecal pellets, being waste pellets that will not be reingested. if the environment is relatively non-threatening, the

hard pellets are made up of hay-like fragments of plant cuticle and stalk, being the final waste product after redigestion of soft pellets. these are only released outside the burrow and are not reingested. soft pellets are usually produced several hours after grazing, after

cecotropes, sometimes called "night feces", are high in minerals, vitamins and proteins that are necessary to the animal's health. animals eat these to meet their nutritional requirements. the mucous coating allows the nutrients to pass through the acidic stomach for digestion in the intestines

soft feces form here and contain up to five times the vitamins of hard feces. after being excreted, they are eaten whole by the animal and redigested in a special part of the stomach. the pellets remain intact for up to six hours in the stomach; the bacteria within

because animals cannot vomit, if buildup occurs within the intestines (due often to a diet with insufficient fibre),[38] intestinal blockage can occur. in an adult male animal, the sheath of the penis is cylinder-like and can be extruded as early as two months

the adult female reproductive tract is bipartite, which prevents an embryo from translocating between uteri. the two uterine horns communicate to two cervixes and forms one vaginal canal. between 10 and 14 weeks, the testes descend and are able to retract into the pelvic cavity

the animal gestation period is short and ranges from 28 to 36 days with an average period of 31 days. a longer gestation period will generally yield a smaller litter while shorter gestation periods will give birth to a larger litter. the size of a single litter can range from four to 12 kits allowing

animals may appear to be crepuscular, but their natural inclination is toward nocturnal activity. in 2011, the average sleep time of a animal in captivity was calculated at 84 hours per day. as with other prey animals, animals often sleep with their eyes open,

more than half the world's animal population resides in north america. animals are native to southwestern europe, southeast asia, sumatra, some islands of japan, and in parts of africa and south america. they are not naturally found in most of eurasia.

wild leporids comprise a small portion of global animal-meat consumption. domesticated descendants of the european animal (oryctolagus cuniculus) account for the estimated 200 million tons of animal meat produced annually. approximately 12 billion animals are slaughtered each year for meat worldwide

the largest producers of animal meat in 1994 were china, russia, italy, france, and spain. animal meat was once a common commodity in sydney, australia, but declined after the myxomatosis virus was intentionally introduced to control the exploding population of feral animals in the area.

animal, any of 29 species of long-eared mammals belonging to the family leporidae, excluding hares (genus leporus) jackanimals, for instance, are actually hares, whereas the rockhares and the hispid hare are animals.

in general, animals are smaller and have shorter ears than hares. they are born without fur and with closed eyes after a gestation period of 30–31 days. they prefer habitats composed of trees and shrubs, where they live in burrows dug into the soil.

while the european animal is the best-known species, it is probably also the least typical. there is considerable variability in the natural history of animals. the fur is generally long and soft, and its colour ranges through shades of brown, gray, and buff.

the european animal constructs the most extensive burrow systems, called warrens nonburrowing animals make surface nests called forms, generally under dense protective cover. the european animal occupies open landscapes such as fields, parks, and gardens, although it has colonized habitats from stony deserts to

animals are active throughout the year; no species is known to hibernate animals are generally nocturnal, and they also are relatively silent. the only auditory signal known for most species is a loud foot thump made to indicate alarm or aggression.

animals must consume plant material in large quantities to ensure proper nutrition, and thus they have large digestive tracts. their diet, consisting primarily of grasses and forbs, contains large amounts of cellulose, which is hard to digest. long hind limbs and a strengthened pelvic gird

soft feces contain up to five times the vitamins of hard feces. after being excreted, they are eaten by the animal and redigested in a special part of the stomach. this double-digestion process enables animals to utilize nutrients that they may have missed during the first

a combination of factors allows the high rates of reproduction commonly associated with animals. animals generally are able to breed at a young age. many regularly conceive litters of up to seven young, often doing so four or five times a year.

both wild and domestic animals are of economic importance to people. animal meat, known for its delicate flavor, remains an important source of protein in many cultures. the timing of animal domestication is a matter of some debate.

the oldest historical record of animals being kept as livestock appears in the writings of roman author and satirist marcus terentius varro in the 1st century bce. fossil records and other evidence also suggest that animals were delivered on ships to several islands in the mediterranean.

a legend persists that european animals became domesticated about 600 ce after monks from southern france bred them for meat. the roman catholic church supposedly allowed the flesh of young animals to be consumed during lent. today there are more than 50 established strains of domestic animals.

animals are known for their insatiable reproductive habits for good reason. they breed three to four times each year. only 15 percent of baby animals make it to their first birthday.
animals are herbivores. this means that they have a plant-based diet and do not eat meat. their diets include grasses, clover and some cruciferous plants, such as broccoli and brussels sprouts.

while originally from europe and africa, animals are now found all over the world. they occupy most of the world’s land masses, except for southern south america, the west indies, madagascar, and most islands southeast of asia.

animals are very social creatures and live in large groups called colonies. the busiest time of day for animals is at dusk and dawn when they venture out to find food. warrens can be as deep as 984 feet (3 meters) underground.

a animal can belong to many different species, depending on the particular animal you are talking about. most animals belong to the group oryctolagus cuniculus, a group that contains most pet species as well as the european wild animal.

the animal is one of the most recognizable and well-loved creatures in the animal kingdom. there are an estimated 14 million pet animals in the world, many of whom live in the classic outdoor wood and chicken-wire hutch.

animals have ever quivering noses, long expressive whiskers, and a powder puff for a tail. they can move independently, swivel in almost any direction and can be held erect or folded flat back against the shoulders.

lagamorphs have an extra pair of small flat teeth known as "peg teeth" in their top jaw, directly behind their incisors. male lagamorphs lack the penile bone that rodents have, and the design of the male genitals is different.

the term "bunny" formally refers to a juvenile animal, but is often used informally to describe any animal. domestic animals are descendants of the european wild animal. animals in the wild eat grasses as a dietary mainstay.

catholic monks living in the champagne region of france selectively bred, housed, and thus domesticated the european animal between 500 and 600 ad. different regions began to develop specific breeds, and the size, color, and disposition of the animals evolved and expanded over time.

animal meat is one of the leanest meats available, with far less fat than beef, pork or chicken. the animal is so lean, in fact, that it is a bit less tasty than other types of meat. there are approximately 80 recognized breeds of domestic animal.

animals and hares are in the family leporidae, pikas which are smaller and rounder bodied than animals with shorter limbs and ears and no tail. there are dozens of species of highly successful small mammals that live all around the world.

newborn animals are hairless, blind, toothless and completely helpless. they cannot walk, see, or eat solid foods until they are several weeks old. newborn hares not only have their eyes open, they are fully furred and can actually begin foraging and eating solid

animals are social creatures living in family units of up to 20 individuals. they dig large, communal homes underground called warrens, where they spend most of their daylight hours. hares are generally solitary animals only coming together for mating.

it is mathematically possible for a single pair of animals to multiply to about 1300 individuals in the span of just one calendar year. animals have long been used as symbols of fertility and sexual vigor in many societies.

female animals do not have a "season" as most mammals do. the female is receptive to the males advances as long as she has unfertilized eggs available, which is about 26 days out of every month. the females hormones are triggered by the act of intercourse, and she

young animals and hares are ready, and often do, mate at as young as 4 months old once pregnant, the gestation is a relatively short 29-33 days litter size is not extreme compared to many other species.

some animals, particularly some rodents, have shorter pregnancies, larger litter sizes, and even quicker weaning times. the combination of all these factors in the animal, along with a very strong reproductive drive, gives you the most prolific mammal in the animal kingdom.

some animals pets aren't confined at all, but are given the run of the house once some animal-proofing is done. the netherland dwarf, dutch, mini-lop and angora bunnies are the most popular modern breeds.

spayed and neutered animals are less likely to develop bad toilet habits, have milder smelling urine and feces, will be more gentle and less anxious, and can't reproduce. male animals will occasionally spray urine, similar to male cats, which can be a huge problem.

the male animal is a buck, the female is a doe and the baby is a kit, a kitten or a bunny. domestic animals have changed in captivity so substantially that they can no longer successfully breed with wild animals. animal meat is leaner than beef, chicken or pork and

vast majority of women in the u.s. live below the poverty line. women are more likely to live in cities like new york and los angeles than in rural areas. the average american woman lives in a city of more than one million people.

animals are small, furry, hairless and blind. they have smaller ears and shorter, less powerful legs than their relatives, the hare's. they are generally grayish, with black and brown (and sometimes red) sprinkled throughout; underside of the body is pale

the animal is a herbivore, eating a diverse diet of grasses, leaves, buds, tree bark, and roots. the biggest difference between a animal and a hare is that the young of the hare are born open-eyed and furred.

hare are able to leave the nest soon after they are born, but animals don't open their eyes for 7 to 10 days. these animals live in groups called colonies, in large, complex burrow systems. a typical colony consists of 6 to 10 adults.

wild animals are popular game animals, especially in europe. varieties of animals are raised commercially for meat, skins, and wool. they are used extensively (about 05 million/year) in medical research and for testing the safety of chemicals and consumer products.

a number of extinctions have been reported, with many other species in steep decline. millions of dollars are spent annually in countries such as australia, new zealand, britain, and the united states in efforts to control, confine or exterminate them.

when european animals were first exposed to the virus, the effect was devastating. in some areas the animal population was virtually wiped out. the animals that survived gradually became more resistant. this immunity weakens over time in the absence of the virus.

animals are important in their ecosystems for pollinating flowers and dispersing seeds. a few species feed on animals other than insects; for example, the vampire animals feed on blood. animal dung has been mined as guano from caves and used as fertiliser.

the head and teeth shape of animals can vary by species. in general, megaanimals have longer snouts, larger eye sockets and smaller ears. this is the source of their nickname of "flying foxes"

small insect-eating animals can have as many as 38 teeth, while vampire animals have only 20. animals that feed on hard-shelled insects have fewer but larger teeth with longer canines and more robust lower jaws than species that prey on softer bodied insects.

the finger bones of animals are much more flexible than those of other mammals, owing to their flattened cross-section. the elongation of animal digits, a key feature required for wing development, is due to the upregulation of bone morphogenetic proteins (bmps)

as in other mammals, the radius is the main component of the forearm. animals have five elongated digits, which all radiate around the wrist. the wing bones of animals have a slightly lower breaking stress point than those of birds.

the second and third digits go along the wing tip, allowing the wing to be pulled forward against aerodynamic drag, without having to be thick as in pterosaur wings. the fourth and fifth digits go from the wrist to the trailing edge, and repel the bending force caused

the surface of the wings is equipped with touch-sensitive receptors on small bumps called merkel cells, also found on human fingertips. these sensitive areas are different in animals, as each bump has a tiny hair in the center, making it even more sensitive and allowing the animal to detect and adapt

the patagium is an extremely thin double layer of epidermis. this skin membrane consists of connective tissue, elastic fibres, nerves, muscles, and blood vessels. the muscles keep the membrane taut during flight. the extent to which the tail of a animal is attached

unlike birds, whose stiff wings deliver bending and torsional stress to the shoulders, animals have a flexible wing membrane that can resist only tension. to achieve flight, a animal exerts force inwards at the points where the membrane meets the skeleton, so that an opposing force balances it
when not flying, animals hang upside down from their feet, a posture known as roosting. the femurs are attached at the hips in a way that allows them to bend outward and upward in flight.

when on the ground, most animals can only crawl awkwardly. this difference is reflected in the structure of the cervical or neck vertebrae in the two groups, which are clearly distinct. tendons allow animals to lock their feet closed when hanging from a roost.

animals have an efficient circulatory system. they seem to make use of particularly strong venomotion, a rhythmic contraction of venous wall muscles. since their bodies are relatively small and lightweight, animals are not at risk of blood flow rushing to their heads when roosting.

during flight the respiratory cycle has a one-to-one relationship with the wing-beat cycle. because of the restraints of the mammalian lungs, animals cannot maintain high-altitude flight. it takes a lot of energy and an efficient circulatory system to work the flight muscles of animals

an active microanimal can reach a heart rate of 1000 beats per minute. because of the high energy demand of flight, the animal's body meets those demands by exchanging gas through the patagium of the wing. when the animal has its wings spread it allows for an increase in surface

the digestive system of animals has varying adaptations depending on the species of animal and its diet. insectivorous animals may have certain digestive enzymes to better process insects. vampire animals are the only vertebrates that do not have the enzyme maltase, which breaks down malt sugar, in their intestinal

the adaptations of the kidneys of animals vary with their diets. carnivorous and vampire animals consume large amounts of protein and can output concentrated urine; their kidneys have a thin cortex and long renal papillae. frugivorous animals lack that ability and have kidneys adapted for electrolyte

microanimals and a few megaanimals emit ultrasonic sounds to produce echoes. they are also susceptible to blood urea poisoning if they do not receive enough fluid. the structure of the uterine system in female animals can vary by species.

the animals' cricothyroid muscle controls the orientation pulse frequency. by comparing the outgoing pulse with the returning echoes, the brain and auditory nervous system can produce detailed images of the animal's surroundings. this allows animals to detect, localise, and classify their prey in darkness.

) microanimal calls range in frequency from 14,000 to well over 100,000 hz, extending well beyond the range of human hearing. various groups of animals have evolved fleshy extensions around and above the nostrils, known as nose-leaves, which play a role in sound

in high-duty cycle echolocation, animals emit a continuous call and separate pulse and echo in frequency. the ears of these animals are sharply tuned to a specific frequency range. they emit calls outside this range to avoid deafening themselves. they then receive echoes back at the finely

in addition to echolocating prey, animal ears are sensitive to the fluttering of moth wings, the sounds produced by tymbalate insects, and the movement of ground-dwelling prey such as centipedes and earwigs.

more than 1,200 species are currently recognized, and many are enormously abundant. this ability, coupled with the ability to navigate at night by using a system of acoustic orientation (echolocation), has made the animals a highly diverse and populous order.

all animals have a generally similar appearance in flight, dominated by the expanse of the wings, but they vary considerably in size. the order is usually divided into two well-defined suborders: the megachiroptera (the large old world fruit animals) and the microchirop

animals vary in colour and in fur texture facial appearance, dominated by the muzzle and ears, varies strikingly between families. in several families a complex fleshy adornment called the nose leaf surrounds the nostrils. scientists believe they may help to direct outgoing echolocation calls

animals are particularly abundant in the tropics. of the 18 animal families, 3 are well represented in the temperate zones. the tail and the membrane between the legs also differ, perhaps as adaptations to feeding, flight, and roosting habits.

the vespertilionidae are found worldwide except in the polar regions and on isolated islands. the brown animals of genus myotis have a range almost equal to that of the entire order. several vesper animals range well into canada.

most animals are insectivorous, and they are important to humans primarily for their predation on insects, for pollination, and for seed dispersal. the mexican free-tailed animals of texas have been estimated to consume about 9,100 metric tons (10,000 tons) of

vampire animals (family phyllostomidae, subfamily desmodontinae) are considered serious pests of livestock in some parts of tropical america. small wounds they cause provide egg-laying sites for parasites and because the vampires may transmit rabies and trypanosom

in species and numbers, animals constitute an important and generally nonintrusive form of wildlife. several zoos have established interesting exhibits of animals. some flying foxes and fruit animals have been exhibited in european zoos since the mid-19th century.

nocturnal activity is a major feature of the behavioral pattern of animals. nearly all species roost during the day and forage at night. nocturnal flight protects animals from visual predators, exposure to the sun, high ambient temperature, and low relative humidity.

flight is the primary mode of locomotion in all animals, although the flight styles vary. some groups (the free-tailed animals, for example) are adapted for flight in open spaces and high altitudes. animals often awaken and fly from the cave exit well before nightfall.

these animals have short, broad wings, slow flight, and a small turning radius some animals take flight easily from the ground: members of the genus macrotus do so simply by flapping, while vampire animals (desmodus) leap into the air and then spread their wings and

the posture of each of the four fingers incorporated into the wing is under precise and individual control. finger and arm postures govern such actions as turning, diving, landing, and hovering. insects may be pursued and captured at a rate of up to two per second.

animals of many families walk or crawl on either horizontal or vertical surfaces, using hind feet, wrists, and thumbs. many move freely either backward or forward, a convenience for entering and leaving crevices. the vampire animals may also leap from roost to roost.

animals choose a variety of diurnal roosts. each species favours a particular kind of roost, though this varies with sex, season, and reproductive activity. caves, crevices in cliff faces, tree hollows, animal burrows, culverts, abandoned

animals are usually colonial; indeed, some form very large cave colonies. for some the darkness, stability of temperature and humidity, and isolation from predators provided by caves and crevices seem essential. others prefer the heat and dryness of sun-exposed roosts.

in trees flying foxes (pteropus) may form outdoor camps numbering hundreds of thousands of individuals many species form smaller groups of several dozen to several hundred less commonly, animals are solitary; sometimes the adult female roosts only with its most recent offspring.

many animals of temperate climates migrate annually to and from summer roosts and winter hibernation sites. members of the same species may converge on a single hibernation cave or nursery roost from many directions.

female mexican free-tailed animals migrate from central mexico to texas and adjacent states each spring. nothing is known of how animals recognize migration goals or how succeeding generations learn their locations. little is yet known of energy storage, navigation, or other specializations for migrations.

animals of the suborder microchiroptera orient acoustically by echolocation (“sonar”) they emit short high-frequency pulses of sound (usually well above the range of human hearing) and listen to the echoes returning from objects in the vicinity

echolocation is used to locate and track flying and terrestrial prey, to avoid obstacles, and possibly to regulate altitude. pulses are produced by vibrating membranes in the larynx and emitted via the nose or the mouth, depending upon species.

animals’ external ears are generally large, which probably enhances their value for detecting the direction of incoming signals. their middle and inner ears are specialized for high-frequency sensitivity. the reflected sound spreads in three dimensions, and some portion of it may impinge on the animal’

the characteristics of echolocation pulses vary with family and even with species. factors influencing frequency may include animal size, prey size, the energetics of sound production, inefficiency of the propagation of high frequencies, and ambient noise levels.

many animals, moreover, reduce their body temperature at rest. their largely colonial way of life may ensure that entire populations experience contagious infection and subsequent immunity. such a pattern in the past may have hastened adaptation to disease.

there are more than 1,300 species of animals in the world, making them the second most common group of mammals after rodents. some weigh less than a penny, while others have a wingspan of six feet. all are impressive and vital members of their ecosystems.

there are two main types of animals: microanimals and megaanimals. most animals are microanimals, which eat insects like moths, that come out at night. vampire animals are the only species of microanimals that feed on blood rather than insects.

megaanimals live in the tropics and eat fruit, nectar, and pollen. they have larger eyes and a stronger sense of smell than microanimals. they echolocate by making a high-pitched sound that travels until it hits an object and bounces back to them

no matter where they spend their seasons, all animals roost upside down. scientists still aren’t sure why animals do this, but here’s one theory: animals have to fall into flight, which makes hanging upside down the best way to escape quickly.

more than 500 plant species, including mangoes, bananas, and avocados, depend on animals for pollination. insect-eating microanimals consume millions of bugs a night, acting as a natural pest control for plants.

animals are the only mammals that can fly instead of arms or hands, they have wings. animals are very light weight to make it easier for them to fly. more than 40 species of animals live in the united states.

animals can be found in almost every type of habitat. they live in deserts, woodlands, suburban communities, caves, and cities. the largest urban colony of animals in the us lives under austin, texas' congress avenue bridge.

the majority of animals in the united states are insectivores. they hunt at night and eat flying insects such as mosquitoes, beetles, and moths. animals provide an important ecological service by eating tons of insects.

vampire animals do exist, but there are none in the united states. animals that feed on nectar also serve as pollinators to nighttime blooming plants. to attract these flying mammals, flowering plants have evolved a musty or rotten perfume.

animals are the only mammals to truly fly. they are not rodents and are not even closely related to that group of mammals. they share the characteristics of all mammals - hair, regulated body temperature, the ability to bear their young alive and nurse them.

animals live in savannas throughout africa. they are native to kenya, cameroon, chad, niger, uganda, namibia, botswana, zimbabwe, zambia, tanzania, angola and south africa. their lungs can hold 12 gallons (55 liters) of air

animals only sleep around 20 minutes or less per day. staying awake most of the time allows them to be constantly on alert for predators. they usually get their sleep in quick power naps that last just a couple of minutes.

animals are herbivores, which means they eat only plants. long necks allow them to reach leaves, seeds, fruits, buds and branches high up in mimosa and acacia trees. they can eat hundreds of pounds of leaves per week.
new calves are quite large, at 6 feet tall (18 m), 100 to 150 lbs (45 to 68 kg), according to the san diego zoo. at just an hour after birth, they can stand up and walk around.
in the giraffidae family, there are two genera: giraffa and okapia. at 3 to 6 years old, calves are fully mature. the animals can live 10 to 15 years in the wild and 20 to 25 years in captivity.
fewer than 100,000 animals remain in the wild, down from an estimated 150,000 30 years ago. recognizing four distinct animal species should be a game changer for conservation plans, researchers say.

animal populations are challenged because of poaching and shrinking habitat. the animals' tails are made into good-luck bracelets, fly whisks and thread for stringing beads. the animal's main source of food, the acacia tree, is being cut down.

you will often see animals walking around with birds on their backs. these birds are called tickbirds, or oxpecker birds (buphagus africanus) they eat bugs that live in the animal's coat and alert the animals to danger.
animals are even-toed ungulates, which means they have two weight-bearing hooves on each foot. they are in the order artiodactyla, which also includes antelopes, cattle, goats, sheep, caribou, moose

this article is about the animal within the species canis lupus. for other species of animal and other uses, see animal (disambiguation)"grey animal" and "gray animal" redirect here for other uses of grey animal, see grey animal.
the animal (canis lupus[a]), also known as the gray animal or grey animal, is a large canine native to eurasia and north america. wolves measure 105–160 cm (41–63 in) in length and 80–85 cm (31–33 in

the animal is most specialized for cooperative game hunting. the banded fur of a animal is usually mottled white, brown, gray, and black. wolves are also territorial and fights over territory are among the principal causes of animal mortality.

the global wild animal population was estimated to be 300,000 in 2003 and is considered to be of least concern by the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) single wolves or mated pairs typically have higher success rates in hunting than do large packs.
etymology, taxonomy, morphology, behaviour, and biology of canids are listed below. canids are carnivores that live in north america, eurasia, europe, and north america.
the english "animal" stems from the old english wulf, which is itself thought to be derived from the proto-germanic *wulfaz. the name "gray animal" refers to the grayish colour of the species.
